mdm_suggested: {"complexity": {"problems": [{"type": "CHRONIC_PROGRESSION", "meta": {"name": "Extranodal Marginal Zone Lymphoma", "details": "Active lymphoma undergoing chemotherapy treatment with BR, affecting parotid gland and lungs with associated pulmonary fibrosis"}}, {"type": "CHRONIC_STABLE", "meta": {"name": "Pulmonary fibrosis", "details": "Bilateral pulmonary fibrosis secondary to lymphoma, condition is irreversible but symptoms showing improvement"}}]}, "risk": {"type": "HIGH", "meta": {"rationale": "Patient receiving Bendamustine-Rituximab chemotherapy which requires intensive monitoring for toxicity"}}, "data": {"items": [{"type": "ORDER_TEST", "meta": {"name": "Blood work", "context": "To assess need for continued allopurinol and monitor treatment"}}, {"type": "ORDER_TEST", "meta": {"name": "PET/CT scan", "context": "Scheduled after completion of cycle 6 chemotherapy"}}, {"type": "REVIEW_RESULT", "meta": {"name": "Laboratory values", "context": "Review of WBC (4.9) and hemoglobin (12.2)"}}]}}
coding_information:
VISIT TYPE: Outpatient
NEW OR FOLLOW-UP: Follow-up
Complexity:
DIAGNOSIS: Extranodal Marginal Zone Lymphoma of the Parotid Gland and Lungs (Stage I) and Pulmonary fibrosis
ONSET: Chronic
STATUS: Stable

COMPLEXITY: HIGH COMPLEXITY
Data:
IDENTIFIED CATEGORY 1: TEST and DOCUMENTS
1. Prior external notes were reviewed.
2. TEST: PET/CT scans report was reviewed and were ordered.

IDENTIFIED CATEGORY 2: INDEPENDENT INTERPRETATION OF TESTS 
1. TEST: Biopsies, CAT scan, and PET scan were personally reviewed and interpreted and/or discussed with external physician/other qualified health care professionals.

IDENTIFIED CATEGORY 3: DISCUSSION OF MANAGEMENT OR TEST INTERPRETATION
1. DISCUSSION: Discussion with external physician/other qualified health care professionals in scheduling PET/CT scans, reviewing test results, and Chemotherapy treatment.

DATA REVIEWED AND/OR ANALYZED: HIGH

Risk:
HIGH RISK
    1. DECISION: Continue with Bendamustine-Rituximab chemotherapy regimen for cycles 4-6, schedule PET/CT scan after completion of cycle 6, assess need for continued allopurinol based on today's blood work, refill omeprazole for acid reflux symptoms and transitioning to surveillance after cycle 6 with PET/CT scans every 6 months for 2 years, then annually for 3 years.
        REASON: Drug therapy for marginal zone lymphoma and managing patient's symptoms.
ordered_medical_tests: [{'test_date': '', 'test_due_duration': 'six months', 'test_type': 'PETCT scan'}, {'test_date': '', 'test_due_duration': 'three to four months', 'test_type': 'blood tests'}]
plan:
Continue with Bendamustine-Rituximab chemotherapy regimen for cycles 4-6.
Schedule PET/CT scan after completion of cycle 6.
Continue allergy medication without interruption through end of treatment.
Assess need for continued allopurinol based on today's blood work.
Refill omeprazole for acid reflux symptoms.
Encourage increased water intake, especially during hot weather.
Use stool softener/laxative as needed for constipation.
Continue regular exercise routine to help manage treatment side effects.
Plan for transition to surveillance after cycle 6 with PET/CT scans every 6 months for 2 years, then annually for 3 years.
Schedule follow-up blood tests every 3-4 months.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.

[['CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Gastric mass on EGD, anemia

DISEASE HISTORY:
10/02/2024: WBC 7.77 (4-10.10), Hemoglobin 11.3 (11-15.5), Hematocrit 35.6 (31.5-44.8), MCV 89.9 (78-98), RDW 14.2 (12-15.5), Platelets 257 (140-425), Ferritin 14 (10-150), Iron 28 (37-145), Iron saturation 8 (12-25), TIBC 349 (228-428), C-reactive protein 0.4 (<0.5). EGD, 9/6/24: Duodenum: Normal duodenal mucosa with preserved villous architecture and no Intraepithelial lymphocytosis. Negative for active celiac disease. Stomach, antrum: Minor reactive gastropathy change, special stain Giemsa is negative for H. pylori microorganisms. No evidence of intestinal metaplasia (PASAB stain). Stomach, anterior wall: Superficial fragments of gastric hyperplastic polyp with at least low grade dysplasia and Giemsa stain is negative for H. pylori, see comment. Special stain PASAB is confirmatory of intestinal metaplasia. Stomach, proximal wall: Superficial fragments of hyperplastic polyp, special stain Giemsa is negative for H. pylori microorganisms. No evidence of intestinal metaplasia (PASAB stain). CBC, 8/28/24: H/H 9.9/31.5, platelets 251. Fe studies, 8/28/24: Fe, 100; TIBC, 356; saturation, 28.8/6/24: Feeling faint. Called 911, Bp 81/35 in ambulance. Hydrated and discharged next day. Hgb low. Iron low.

INTERVAL HISTORY:
1/17/25: 
Patient underwent ultrasound which revealed a 2.5 cm gastric tumor, previously characterized as a polyp. Upper endoscopy performed on 1/16/25 identified and removed three new small polyps with clip placement. Imaging revealed an incidental pancreatic lesion. Patient denies hematemesis, melena, hematochezia, hemoptysis, epistaxis, gingival bleeding, or hematuria. Recent blood work from 1/7/25 shows normalized iron levels, leading to discontinuation of iron supplementation. Carotid ultrasound and non-contrast CT stable over two-year period.

ALLERGIES:
No known allergies
No known drug allergies

MEDICATIONS:
Continued medications: Eye Multivitamin 2148 mcg-113 mg-45 mg-17.4 mg tablet, ezetimibe 10 mg tablet, FAMOTIDINE 40 MG TABLET, FreeStyle Lite Strips, levothyroxine 75 mcg tablet, Ozempic 2 mg/dose (8 mg/3 mL) subcutaneous pen injector, Repatha SureClick 140 mg/mL subcutaneous pen injector, solifenacin 10 mg tablet, Trelegy Ellipta 100 mcg-62.5 mcg-25 mcg powder for inhalation, Vascepa 1 gram capsule.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well-developed, well-nourished.
HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear.
Nodes: No peripheral adenopathy.
Chest: Clear bilaterally.
Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat.
Abd: Soft, +BS, non-tender and non-distended, no masses, no organomegaly.
Ext: No edema.
Skin: No rash.
Neuro: Motor and sensory grossly intact.
Musculoskeletal: Normal gait.

IMPRESSION:
Gastric polyp with low-grade dysplasia. Awaiting surgical consultation for removal. 
Anemia (mild, currently near normal limits). Hemoglobin level is now 10.8 g/dL.
Gastric tumor 2.5 cm, requiring surgical removal. No new gastrointestinal bleeding symptoms reported. 
Pancreatic lesion identified on CT, further evaluation pending.

PLAN:
Proceed with CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis with contrast to evaluate the gastric mass and pancreatic lesion.
Schedule blood tests to include BUN to assess renal function pre-contrast CT.
Consultation with a surgeon is already scheduled for the upcoming Thursday to discuss surgical options for tumor removal.
Encourage smoking cessation to reduce cancer recurrence risk and support overall health.
Patient education on the importance of ongoing monitoring post-surgery and need for follow-up based on CT scan results.
Ensure communication regarding updates on the surgical plan and additional findings post-imaging.
Reiterate the potential risks and complications of smoking related to cancer recurrence and overall health.', 0], ['CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and management of colon cancer and non-small cell lung cancer.

DISEASE HISTORY:
1. Laparoscopic converted to open right hemicolectomy 5/3/2022.  pT1, N0 invasive adenocarcinoma.  19 negative lymph nodes.
2. Spiculated left upper lobe mass, biopsy reveals invasive non-small cell lung cancer, immunohistochemical profile consistent with squamous cell carcinoma.
3. Robot-assisted thorascopic left upper lobectomy with mediastinal lymph node dissection on 7/18/2022. Pathology revealed a T2a, N0, MX invasive squamous cell carcinoma, moderately differentiated, grade II, 3.4 cm with negative margins.

INTERVAL HISTORY:
03/27/25: 
Patient presents for routine oncology follow-up. Patient reports doing well from cancer perspective with no new complaints or symptoms. Denies abdominal pain. Reports decreased appetite, which patient attributes to hospitalization experiences during cancer treatment rather than current symptoms. Bowel movements have been problematic lately but patient states it is under control now. Patient has had multiple cardiac procedures since last oncology visit: six stents placed in 11/24, TAVR surgery on 12/17/24, and new defibrillator placement on 3/20/25. Patient reports soreness at defibrillator site one week post-procedure. Patient is currently without evidence of disease recurrence. Cancer markers were reported as normal on previous testing. Most recent CT scan on 10/10/24 showed no evidence of recurrence in lungs or liver. Patient has passed the two-year mark post-treatment and will transition to annual imaging surveillance.

ALLERGIES:
No known allergies.
No known drug allergies.

MEDICATIONS:
Added medication: tamsulosin 0.4 mg capsule. Continued medications: albuterol sulfate HFA 90 mcg/actuation aerosol inhaler, Allegra-D 24 Hour 180 mg-240 mg tablet extended release, azelastine 137 mcg (0.1 %) nasal spray aerosol, digoxin 125 mcg (0.125 mg) tablet, Eliquis 5 mg tablet, fluticasone propionate 50 mcg/actuation blister powder for inhalation, ipratropium 0.5 mg-albuterol 3 mg (2.5 mg base)/3 mL nebulization soln, losartan 25 mg tablet, metoprolol succinate ER 50 mg tablet extended release 24 hr, Nitrostat 0.4 mg sublingual tablet, pantoprazole 40 mg tablet delayed release, PreserVision AREDS 2148 mcg-113 mg-45 mg-17.4 mg tablet, Probiotic 10 billion cell capsule, rosuvastatin 10 mg tablet, Trelegy Ellipta 100 mcg-62.5 mcg-25 mcg powder for inhalation, Vitamin B-12 500 mcg tablet, vitamin E 400 unit capsule.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below.

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed, well nourished.
HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear.
Nodes: No peripheral adenopathy.
Chest: Clear bilaterally, lungs sound clear with no fluid detected.
Heart: S1, S2, no murmurs, regular heartbeat.
Abd: Soft, +BS, non-tender and non-distended, no masses, no organomegaly.
Ext: No edema.
Skin: No rash.
Neuro: Motor and sensory grossly intact.
Musculoskeletal: Normal gait.

IMPRESSION:
1. T1, N0 colon cancer with 19 negative LN, negative margins. MLH1 / PMS2 expression absent. Promoter hypermethylation pending. No new abdominal pain or concerns; appetite continues to be reduced post-surgery.
2. NSCLC: Stage IB, T2a, N0 invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Now status post left upper lobectomy. Recent CT scan (10/10/24) shows no recurrence in the lungs. Blood work shows normal cancer markers.
3. Tubular adenomas.
4. Loss of MLH1/PMS2: BRAF was mutated; MLH1 Promoter Region Methylation Detected.

PLAN:
Schedule follow-up CAT scan in October 2025 to monitor for recurrence.
Continue biannual follow-up appointments for oncology management.
Monitor laboratory results and inform the patient only if issues are detected.
Continue current medication regimen with newly added tamsulosin.
Follow up with CAT scan results and management plan after the October scan.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.

IMPRESSION:
36-year-old woman with a history of metastatic breast cancer currently receiving Enhertu. She has no prior history of thrombotic or embolic events and no history of miscarriages. There is no family history of thrombotic events. She was treated with 1 dose of Lovenox and then began Rivaroxaban 15 mg twice daily and will be on this for 21 days before she is transitioned to 20 mg daily.

December 27, 2023–history of metastatic breast cancer currently receiving Enhertu with recent scan showing response. Unfortunately the scans made no comment on the previously seen right ovarian vein thrombosis. She comes in without any complaints of abdominal pain, bleeding or abdominal distention.

May 13, 2024–breast cancer, metastatic, she has remained on Enhertu without any significant side effects. She is currently on Xarelto 20 mg daily for a right ovarian vein thrombosis that extended directly to the level of the IVC. She denies any abdominal pain and has had no bleeding.

May 06, 2025–Patient continues on Xarelto for ovarian vein thrombosis with no complications. Transvaginal ultrasound from February showed normal appearing uterus and ovaries with patent IVC and left veins. No clots were visualized. Patient has intermittent epistaxis likely related to allergies/dry air. She continues to experience post-treatment fatigue. Lab work from March showed iron saturation of 10%, low-normal B12 (496), and vitamin D deficiency (10). Patient had iron infusions in March. She reports using liquid IV for hydration which has helped with post-treatment symptoms.

PLAN:
Continue Xarelto 20 mg daily for ovarian vein thrombosis.
Recommend nasal saline, humidifier, and aquaphor inside nostrils for epistaxis.
Consider Claritin for allergy symptoms.
Complete prescription vitamin D and then transition to 2,000 IU daily maintenance.
Obtain stool sample to check for occult blood.
Lab work to include iron studies, B12, and vitamin D levels at next MSK visit.
Request copy of upcoming PET scan results.
Take vitamin D in morning and multivitamin 1-2 hours after breakfast.
Follow up in 6 months with lab work prior to appointment.
Avoid aspirin, NSAIDs while on anticoagulation.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.', 0]]
reviewed_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and management of marginal zone lymphoma of the parotid gland

DISEASE HISTORY:
The  patient  has  a  known  diagnosis  of  Extranodal  Marginal  Zone  Lymphoma  of  the  Parotid  Gland  previously  determined  to  be  Stage IE,  following  surgical  excision.  Historical  PET  CT  scans  indicated  no  detectable  malignancy  beyond  the  localized  site.  A  recent biopsy,  however,  from  a  bronchoscopic  procedure  has  indicated  involvement  in  the  lung,  suggesting  further  spread. 04/15/25:  Patient  presents  for  followup  of  marginal  zone  lymphoma.  Outside  review  of  biopsies  at  MSK  confirmed  marginal  zone lymphoma  in  both  parotid  gland  and  lung  biopsy.  Imaging  review  with  radiologists  from  both  institutions  revealed  evidence  of pulmonary  fibrosis  in  both  lungs,  which  is  believed  to  be  related  to  the  lymphoma.  Patient  reports  feeling  well  currently.  CAT  scan from  November  2024  showed  the  same  pattern  of  fibrosis  that  was  later  seen  on  PET  scan.  Pulmonary  fibrosis  is  noted  to  be irreversible.  No  recent  respiratory  symptoms  reported.05/19/25:  Patient  presents  for  first  chemotherapy  treatment  with  Bendamustine­Rituximab  regimen.  Patient  reports  experiencing night  sweats  and  occasional  chills,  but  denies  fevers.  Patient  notes  some  shortness  of  breath  when  climbing  stairs  but  not  at  rest. Patient  reports  decreased  water  intake  compared  to  his  previous  habits.  Patient  is  currently  taking  an  antibiotic  for  a  tooth  infection, which  is  improving.  Patient  also  reports  having  pulmonary  fibrosis  with  persistent  phlegm  that  he  has  difficulty  expectorating,  and notes  one  episode  where  he  coughed  up  blood.  Patient  has  contacted  his  pulmonologist  about  this  issue.

INTERVAL HISTORY:
08/11/25: Rafael presents for follow-up and fourth cycle of Bendamustine-Rituximab chemotherapy. He reports significant improvement in cough symptoms, which is consistent with positive response to treatment. Rafael has gained weight, increasing from 191 to 201 pounds. He reports experiencing occasional constipation during his third cycle, with two episodes of difficult bowel movements, but denies current issues. He continues to exercise regularly at the gym. Rafael reports experiencing fatigue, particularly after eating. He also mentions occasional acid reflux. No neuropathy, numbness, or tingling in extremities reported. The parotid area is healing well with only localized numbness at the surgical site.

ALLERGIES:
No known allergies
No known drug allergies

MEDICATIONS:
Continued medications: Akynzeo (fosnetupitant) 235 mg-0.25 mg intravenous powder for solution, ALLOPURINOL 300MG TABLETS, bendamustine 100 mg intravenous powder for solution, bendamustine 100 mg intravenous powder for solution, prednisone 2.5 mg tablet, Riabni 10 mg/mL intravenous solution, SULFAMETHOXAZOLE/TRIMETHOPRIM DS  800-160 MG TABS, Treanda 100 mg intravenous powder for solution.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. HEENT:PERRLA,EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear. Nodes: No peripheral adenopathy. Chest: Clear bilaterally. Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat. Abd: Soft, +BS, non tender and non distended, no masses, no organomegaly. Ext: No edema. Skin: no rash. Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact. Musculoskeletal: Normal gait.

IMPRESSION:
1.  Extranodal  Marginal  Zone  Lymphoma  of  the  Parotid  Gland  and  Lungs  (Stage  I):  MSK  review  confirmed  marginal  zone  lymphoma in  both  parotid  gland  and  lung  biopsies.  Imaging  shows  evidence  of  pulmonary  fibrosis  in  both  lungs  believed  to  be  related  to  the lymphoma.  This  is  a  rare  presentation,  with  less  than  5%  of  marginal  zone  lymphoma  cases  reported  worldwide  involving  the  lungs. The  lymphoma  is  likely  to  have  been  present  for  years  before  detection,  which  is  typical  of  this  indolent  disease.  Treatment  is recommended  due  to  the  presence  of  fibrosis.  Patient  is  continuing BR  (Bendamustine­Rituximab)  chemotherapy  today. He reports only mild fatigue and occasional cold sensations. Laboratory values remain stable with normal white blood cell count (4.9) and hemoglobin (12.2). Patient's weight has increased from 191 to 201 pounds, which he attributes to improved exercise routine. Treatment is addressing the nodular pattern observed in the lungs. Significant improvement in persistent cough noted, suggesting positive response to treatment.
2.  Pulmonary  fibrosis:  Bilateral  pulmonary  fibrosis  noted  on  imaging,  now  confirmed  to  be  related  to  the  underlying  lymphoma.  This is  an  irreversible  condition.  Patient  is  unusually  young  to  have  developed  pulmonary  fibrosis,  supporting  the  connection  to  the lymphoma  rather  than  environmental  exposures  or  idiopathic  causes.  Patient  reports  persistent  phlegm  with  difficulty  expectorating and  one  episode  of  hemoptysis.  Patient  will  be  following  up  with  his  pulmonologist  regarding  these  symptoms.  Patient reports marked improvement in cough symptoms.

PLAN:
Continue with Bendamustine-Rituximab chemotherapy regimen for cycles 4-6.
Schedule PET/CT scan after completion of cycle 6.
Continue allergy medication without interruption through end of treatment.
Assess need for continued allopurinol based on today's blood work.
Refill omeprazole for acid reflux symptoms.
Encourage increased water intake, especially during hot weather.
Use stool softener/laxative as needed for constipation.
Continue regular exercise routine to help manage treatment side effects.
Plan for transition to surveillance after cycle 6 with PET/CT scans every 6 months for 2 years, then annually for 3 years.
Schedule follow-up blood tests every 3-4 months.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.

Patient's weight has increased from 191 to 201 pounds, which he attributes to improved exercise routine. Treatment is addressing the nodular pattern observed in the lungs. Significant improvement in persistent cough noted, suggesting positive response to treatment.
2.  Pulmonary  fibrosis:  Bilateral  pulmonary  fibrosis  noted  on  imaging,  now  confirmed  to  be  related  to  the  underlying  lymphoma.  This is  an  irreversible  condition.  Patient  is  unusually  young  to  have  developed  pulmonary  fibrosis,  supporting  the  connection  to  the lymphoma  rather  than  environmental  exposures  or  idiopathic  causes.  Patient  reports  persistent  phlegm  with  difficulty  expectorating and  one  episode  of  hemoptysis.  Patient  will  be  following  up  with  his  pulmonologist  regarding  these  symptoms.  Patient reports marked improvement in cough symptoms.

Continue with Bendamustine-Rituximab chemotherapy regimen for cycles 4-6.
Schedule PET/CT scan after completion of cycle 6.
Continue allergy medication without interruption through end of treatment.
Assess need for continued allopurinol based on today's blood work.
Refill omeprazole for acid reflux symptoms.
Encourage increased water intake, especially during hot weather.
Use stool softener/laxative as needed for constipation.
Continue regular exercise routine to help manage treatment side effects.
Plan for transition to surveillance after cycle 6 with PET/CT scans every 6 months for 2 years, then annually for 3 years.
Schedule follow-up blood tests every 3-4 months.

summarize_job_log.1:prompt:
[{'content': 'You are a doctor named:Dr.AmitPatel writing a visit note for patient:Woss, Rafael A. You need to capture as much medical information as possible in a logical way. Do not include headers or similar artificial headings. Start directly with the note format.', 'role': 'system'}, {'content': 'You are an oncologist named:Dr.AmitPatel writing a visit note for patient:Woss, Rafael A.
The date of appointment is 8/11/2025, use this date when required in the note and note the year. Write in MM/DD/YY format.
This is a follow-up visit for a patient. You need to capture all medical information relevant to an oncologist. 
Throughout the note refer to the patient by their first name. If you don't know their gender refer to them by their first name. Do not use "Patient."

I am going to give you a conversation to summarize into a note. Absolutely do not hallucinate any information and stick
strictly to the transcript. Do not get information from anywhere else.

Do not put "the doctor," "the transcript," or "the conversation" anywhere in the note. 
Do not hallucinate age and only include age if found in the transcript.
Stay objective and academic and scientific. Stay objective and concise.

In the "Chief Complaint" section, output what is there verbatim.

For DISEASE HISTORY, sometimes this section will be one paragraph but needs to be formatted. Separate dated entries onto new lines. This section should be formatted for readability. Do not add any information or remove any information, just format this section when needed.

Write INTERVAL HISTORY in concise sentences like an oncologist would. Only include patient symptoms and any updates
on their condition using formal and scientific medical language. Put any discussed lab, imaging, or pathology results
from the transcript in the Interval history as well. Write dates in MM/DD/YY format. Do not hallucinate any lab, imaging,
or pathology results and use the exact stated medical language. Write disease stages in roman numerals. Write all other
numbers in number form.

In IMPRESSION, the goal is to preserve the original content, style, and formatting of the previous impression provided but to update it with the information from the transcript.
Do not remove historic information. Only modify/update any outdated information that is contradicted by new findings.
Do not remove any diagnoses. If a diagnosis is not discussed, leave it as is
If there are new diagnoses, add them to this section in the same formatting as the other diagnoses
It is crucial to maintain as much content, style, and formatting of previous impression formatting as possible


In the "PLAN" section, write each plan item as a short, concise sentence with each sentence on a new line.
- Use direct, clinical language without extra filler or explanation.
- Keep each bullet point to one sentence, limiting it to essential details (e.g., drug, dose, schedule, relevant instructions).
- If a plan item pertains to a date, use MM/DD/YY format. 
- If follow-up is discussed, specify it briefly.

Output only the generated note and nothing else.

Use the provided starting note and fill out the rest of it. Only output the generated note and nothing else. 
Leave Review of Systems as is. For the Physical Examination, if no information is provided or exam dictated,
put the default information from the template. Otherwise update the Physical Examination.

There are also some reference notes from the same doctor, focus on learning the language used, how each note is written,
and formatting and structure of each section of the reference notes. Reference these notes when writing the new note
if it is helpful. Absolutely do not hallucinate.

Do not use Markdown formatting. Do not prefix headings with "#" or any special characters.

Make sure the knowtex privacy/consent line is present in the output.

Are you ready?

Evaluation and management of marginal zone lymphoma of the parotid gland

December 27, 2023–history of metastatic breast cancer currently receiving Enhertu with recent scan showing response. Unfortunately the scans made no comment on the previously seen right ovarian vein thrombosis. She comes in without any complaints of abdominal pain, bleeding or abdominal distention.

May 13, 2024–breast cancer, metastatic, she has remained on Enhertu without any significant side effects. She is currently on Xarelto 20 mg daily for a right ovarian vein thrombosis that extended directly to the level of the IVC. She denies any abdominal pain and has had no bleeding.

May 06, 2025–Patient continues on Xarelto for ovarian vein thrombosis with no complications. Transvaginal ultrasound from February showed normal appearing uterus and ovaries with patent IVC and left veins. No clots were visualized. Patient has intermittent epistaxis likely related to allergies/dry air. She continues to experience post-treatment fatigue. Lab work from March showed iron saturation of 10%, low-normal B12 (496), and vitamin D deficiency (10). Patient had iron infusions in March. She reports using liquid IV for hydration which has helped with post-treatment symptoms.

PLAN:
Continue Xarelto 20 mg daily for ovarian vein thrombosis.
Recommend nasal saline, humidifier, and aquaphor inside nostrils for epistaxis.
Consider Claritin for allergy symptoms.
Complete prescription vitamin D and then transition to 2,000 IU daily maintenance.
Obtain stool sample to check for occult blood.
Lab work to include iron studies, B12, and vitamin D levels at next MSK visit.
Request copy of upcoming PET scan results.
Take vitamin D in morning and multivitamin 1-2 hours after breakfast.
Follow up in 6 months with lab work prior to appointment.
Avoid aspirin, NSAIDs while on anticoagulation.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software. 

 [REFERENCE NOTE3 END]

Message(id='msg_01C5d9ahTr5aNP5WFafDeotf', content=[TextBlock(citations=None, text="CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and management of marginal zone lymphoma of the parotid gland

DISEASE HISTORY:
The  patient  has  a  known  diagnosis  of  Extranodal  Marginal  Zone  Lymphoma  of  the  Parotid  Gland  previously  determined  to  be  Stage IE,  following  surgical  excision.  Historical  PET  CT  scans  indicated  no  detectable  malignancy  beyond  the  localized  site.  A  recent biopsy,  however,  from  a  bronchoscopic  procedure  has  indicated  involvement  in  the  lung,  suggesting  further  spread. 04/15/25:  Patient  presents  for  followup  of  marginal  zone  lymphoma.  Outside  review  of  biopsies  at  MSK  confirmed  marginal  zone lymphoma  in  both  parotid  gland  and  lung  biopsy.  Imaging  review  with  radiologists  from  both  institutions  revealed  evidence  of pulmonary  fibrosis  in  both  lungs,  which  is  believed  to  be  related  to  the  lymphoma.  Patient  reports  feeling  well  currently.  CAT  scan from  November  2024  showed  the  same  pattern  of  fibrosis  that  was  later  seen  on  PET  scan.  Pulmonary  fibrosis  is  noted  to  be irreversible.  No  recent  respiratory  symptoms  reported.05/19/25:  Patient  presents  for  first  chemotherapy  treatment  with  Bendamustine\xadRituximab  regimen.  Patient  reports  experiencing night  sweats  and  occasional  chills,  but  denies  fevers.  Patient  notes  some  shortness  of  breath  when  climbing  stairs  but  not  at  rest. Patient  reports  decreased  water  intake  compared  to  his  previous  habits.  Patient  is  currently  taking  an  antibiotic  for  a  tooth  infection, which  is  improving.  Patient  also  reports  having  pulmonary  fibrosis  with  persistent  phlegm  that  he  has  difficulty  expectorating,  and notes  one  episode  where  he  coughed  up  blood.  Patient  has  contacted  his  pulmonologist  about  this  issue.

INTERVAL HISTORY:
08/11/25: Rafael presents for follow-up and fourth cycle of Bendamustine-Rituximab chemotherapy. He reports significant improvement in cough symptoms, which is consistent with positive response to treatment. Rafael has gained weight, increasing from 191 to 201 pounds. He reports experiencing occasional constipation during his third cycle, with two episodes of difficult bowel movements, but denies current issues. He continues to exercise regularly at the gym. Rafael reports experiencing fatigue, particularly after eating. He also mentions occasional acid reflux. No neuropathy, numbness, or tingling in extremities reported. The parotid area is healing well with only localized numbness at the surgical site.

ALLERGIES:
No known allergies
No known drug allergies

MEDICATIONS:
Continued medications: Akynzeo (fosnetupitant) 235 mg-0.25 mg intravenous powder for solution, ALLOPURINOL 300MG TABLETS, bendamustine 100 mg intravenous powder for solution, bendamustine 100 mg intravenous powder for solution, prednisone 2.5 mg tablet, Riabni 10 mg/mL intravenous solution, SULFAMETHOXAZOLE/TRIMETHOPRIM DS  800-160 MG TABS, Treanda 100 mg intravenous powder for solution.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. HEENT:PERRLA,EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear. Nodes: No peripheral adenopathy. Chest: Clear bilaterally. Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat. Abd: Soft, +BS, non tender and non distended, no masses, no organomegaly. Ext: No edema. Skin: no rash. Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact. Musculoskeletal: Normal gait.

IMPRESSION:
1.  Extranodal  Marginal  Zone  Lymphoma  of  the  Parotid  Gland  and  Lungs  (Stage  I):  MSK  review  confirmed  marginal  zone  lymphoma in  both  parotid  gland  and  lung  biopsies.  Imaging  shows  evidence  of  pulmonary  fibrosis  in  both  lungs  believed  to  be  related  to  the lymphoma.  This  is  a  rare  presentation,  with  less  than  5%  of  marginal  zone  lymphoma  cases  reported  worldwide  involving  the  lungs. The  lymphoma  is  likely  to  have  been  present  for  years  before  detection,  which  is  typical  of  this  indolent  disease.  Treatment  is recommended  due  to  the  presence  of  fibrosis.  Patient  is  continuing BR  (Bendamustine\xadRituximab)  chemotherapy  today. He reports only mild fatigue and occasional cold sensations. Laboratory values remain stable with normal white blood cell count (4.9) and hemoglobin (12.2). Patient's weight has increased from 191 to 201 pounds, which he attributes to improved exercise routine. Treatment is addressing the nodular pattern observed in the lungs. Significant improvement in persistent cough noted, suggesting positive response to treatment.
2.  Pulmonary  fibrosis:  Bilateral  pulmonary  fibrosis  noted  on  imaging,  now  confirmed  to  be  related  to  the  underlying  lymphoma.  This is  an  irreversible  condition.  Patient  is  unusually  young  to  have  developed  pulmonary  fibrosis,  supporting  the  connection  to  the lymphoma  rather  than  environmental  exposures  or  idiopathic  causes.  Patient  reports  persistent  phlegm  with  difficulty  expectorating and  one  episode  of  hemoptysis.  Patient  will  be  following  up  with  his  pulmonologist  regarding  these  symptoms.  Patient reports marked improvement in cough symptoms.

PLAN:
Continue with Bendamustine-Rituximab chemotherapy regimen for cycles 4-6.
Schedule PET/CT scan after completion of cycle 6.
Continue allergy medication without interruption through end of treatment.
Assess need for continued allopurinol based on today's blood work.
Refill omeprazole for acid reflux symptoms.
Encourage increased water intake, especially during hot weather.
Use stool softener/laxative as needed for constipation.
Continue regular exercise routine to help manage treatment side effects.
Plan for transition to surveillance after cycle 6 with PET/CT scans every 6 months for 2 years, then annually for 3 years.
Schedule follow-up blood tests every 3-4 months.

plan:
1. Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) - Stable: Continue Silodosin 8mg daily. Patient to continue Prostate S.R. vitamin supplement twice daily. Behavioral modifications, decreasing fluid intake three hours prior to bedtime, and avoiding bladder irritants such as caffeine were discussed. Behavioral modifications, decreasing fluid intake three hours prior to bedtime, and avoiding bladder irritants such as caffeine, alcohol, spicy and acidic foods discussed.

2. Elevated PSA - Monitoring: Current PSA 3.9, slightly elevated from baseline in the low 3s. Will obtain 4K score today to assess risk for prostate cancer. If 4K score shows elevated risk, will consider prostate MRI. If 4K score is reassuring, will continue monitoring. Patient previously had 4K score in 2022. Will repeat PSA in 6 months. I had a discussion with the patient about the significance of elevated PSA. Most common etiologies are BPH, inflammation, infection, or an underlying tumor. The only definitive way to distinguish between these diagnoses is with a prostate biopsy. I have discussed the risks including but not limited to UTI, sepsis, hematuria, hematochezia, hematospermia, and urinary retention.

3. Overactive Bladder (OAB) - Stable: Patient not currently taking Trospium but symptoms appear controlled with current regimen. Treatment options for Overactive Bladder Syndrome (OAB) were discussed. Behavior/lifestyle modifications including modifying voiding habits (timed/delayed voiding, fluid management, pelvic floor exercises, weight loss, and avoiding bladder irritants such as alcoholic beverages, carbonated beverages, spicy/acidic food, chocolate, citrus fruits, apples, coffee/tea, cranberry products, dairy, sugar/sugar substitutes, and vinegar. Treatment with antimuscarinics and beta-3 agonists were discussed. Side effects including constipation, visual changes, dry mouth, hypertension, and changes in memory were explained. Counseled that medications work best when used in combination with behavior/lifestyle modifications. 3rd line treatment options including intravesical Botox, PTNS, and Sacral neuromodulation also discussed.

[{'content': 'You are a medical assistant helping to finalize a doctor’s note.', 'role': 'system'}, {'content': 'You are a medical assistant helping a doctor finalize their clinical note. I will provide you with three inputs:

1- A doctor's note – a preliminary SOAP or visit note.
2️- A dictionary of macros – a set of reusable phrases keyed by relevant medical terms or actions (e.g., "labs reviewed", "follow-up instructions").
3- The transcript of the doctor's visit.

Your tasks:

- Only scan the Plan section of the doctor's note for direct mentions or clear contextual indications of the macro keys from the dictionary. You may also use the transcript to clarify if a macro is contextually implied.
- When you find a match, insert the corresponding macro content at the end of the relevant paragraph within the Plan section.
- **Do not** delete, rewrite, rephrase, or restructure any part of the doctor's note other than inserting the macros where appropriate.
- If no macro is explicitly referenced or clearly implied in the note, do not add it.
- The note’s original structure and content must remain **completely unchanged** other than adding relevant macros in the correct place.

Return only the **final, updated note**—no explanations.

At the end of the note, on a new line, add one of the following summary lines:  
- If no macros were inserted: `No macros added`  
- If macros were inserted: `Macros added: [macro1, macro2]` (replace with actual macro names used)

**Inputs:**  
doctors_note: CHIEF COMPLAINT: Evaluation and management of: BPH and OAB.

HPI: 
Follow-up visit. No new complaints. Good control of urinary symptoms with Rapaflo (silodosin) 8mg daily and Prostate S.R. vitamin supplement twice daily. Patient is not currently taking Trospium as previously prescribed. Patient has been maintaining PSA levels in the low 3s as his baseline, with current PSA at 3.9, showing a slight elevation.

Physical Exam:
Digital rectal examination performed.

Laboratory Results:
PSA: 3.9
Bladder scan: 4 mL

Imaging Results:

Procedure:

Plan:
1. Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH) - Stable: Continue Silodosin 8mg daily. Patient to continue Prostate S.R. vitamin supplement twice daily. Behavioral modifications, decreasing fluid intake three hours prior to bedtime, and avoiding bladder irritants such as caffeine were discussed.

2. Elevated PSA - Monitoring: Current PSA 3.9, slightly elevated from baseline in the low 3s. Will obtain 4K score today to assess risk for prostate cancer. If 4K score shows elevated risk, will consider prostate MRI. If 4K score is reassuring, will continue monitoring. Patient previously had 4K score in 2022. Will repeat PSA in 6 months.

3. Overactive Bladder (OAB) - Stable: Patient not currently taking Trospium but symptoms appear controlled with current regimen. 
dictionary of macros: {'Elevated PSA': 'I had a discussion with the patient about the significance of elevated PSA. Most common etiologies are BPH, inflammation, infection, or an underlying tumor. The only definitive way to distinguish between these diagnoses is with a prostate biopsy. I have discussed the risks including but not limited to UTI, sepsis, hematuria, hematochezia, hematospermia, and urinary retention.', 'Erectile Dysfunction': 'Discussed that erectile function is the result of a complex interplay between vascular, neurologic, hormonal, and psychologic factors. Since the risk of developing ED is increased in the presence of diabetes, heart disease, and hypertension, optimal management of these diseases may prevent the development and progression of ED. Lifestyle modifications such as avoiding smoking, maintaining ideal body weight, and engaging in regular exercise including cardiovascular endurance and strength training discussed.', 'Gross Hematuria': 'A variety of conditions may present with gross hematuria, including infectious, inflammatory, traumatic, neoplastic, nephritic, renal vein thrombosis, bleeding disorders, urolithiasis, and iatrogenic processes. In addition to urine culture to rule out infection, work-up includes urine cytology and upper tract cross sectional imaging (CT or MR Urogram). The lower urinary tract will be evaluated with cystoscopy.', 'Kidney Stones': 'Risk factors for kidney stone formation, and dietary modifications including increasing water intake for prevention discussed.', 'Low Testosterone': 'The patient has a diagnosis of low testosterone defined as < 300 ng/dL on two separate early morning measurements, in the setting of signs/symptoms consistent with the diagnosis. He was informed that low T is a risk factor for cardiovascular disease. Treatment may result in improvements in erectile function, low sex drive, anemia, bone mineral density, lean body mass, and/or depressive symptoms. The benefits of lifestyle modifications including weight loss and exercise, and their effect on improvements in T level were discussed. Contraindications to T therapy are existing prostate / breast cancer, hematocrit level >54%, untreated OSA, untreated severe congestive heart failure, and desired fertility. Risks including polycythemia, infertility, worsening sleep apnea, prostate enlargement, fluid retention, mood changes, gynecomastia, liver toxicity, potential cardiovascular risk discussed. The different forms of testosterone replacement including oral, injections, topical, and pellets discussed. Once initiating treatment or changing dose, labs including CBC, CMP, Estradiol level, Total and free Testosterone are checked 8 weeks later. Routine labs are then checked every 3-6 months. If no symptomatic benefits after 3-6 months of therapy and adequate serum levels, will consider discontinuation of medication.', 'BPH': 'Behavioral modifications, decreasing fluid intake three hours prior to bedtime, and avoiding bladder irritants such as caffeine, alcohol, spicy and acidic foods discussed.', 'Microhematuria': 'The patient has microhematuria defined as 3 or > RBCs/hpf on urinalysis, in the absence of benign etiology. The origins of microhematuria are either urologic or nephrologic. The most common urological etiologies are benign prostatic enlargement, infection, and urinary calculi. The overall urinary tract malignancy rate is approximately 3.3%. This risk increases with age over 35, past or current smoking, occupational or other exposure to chemicals or dyes (benzenes or aromatic amines), history of gross hematuria, irritative voiding symptoms, urologic disorder, pelvic radiation, chronic UTI, exposure to carcinogenic agents/chemotherapy, and chronic indwelling catheterization. The presence of urinary casts, proteins, and/or dysmorphic red blood cells suggests a medical renal etiology. For negative initial work-up, follow-up urinalysis at least once every year for two years is recommended. For patients whose urine is recurrently positive for MH, reevaluation can be done within three to five years of the initial negative workup. Changes in the clinical scenario, such as a substantial increase in the degree of MH, the detection of dysmorphic RBCs with concomitant hypertension and/or proteinuria, the development of gross hematuria, pain, or other new symptoms, may warrant earlier re-evaluation and/or referral to other practitioners such as nephrologists.', 'Overactive Bladder': 'Treatment options for Overactive Bladder Syndrome (OAB) were discussed. Behavior/lifestyle modifications including modifying voiding habits (timed/delayed voiding, fluid management, pelvic floor exercises, weight loss, and avoiding bladder irritants such as alcoholic beverages, carbonated beverages, spicy/acidic food, chocolate, citrus fruits, apples, coffee/tea, cranberry products, dairy, sugar/sugar substitutes, and vinegar. Treatment with antimuscarinics and beta-3 agonists were discussed. Side effects including constipation, visual changes, dry mouth, hypertension, and changes in memory were explained. Counseled that medications work best when used in combination with behavior/lifestyle modifications. 3rd line treatment options including intravesical Botox, PTNS, and Sacral neuromodulation also discussed.', 'Any discussion on surgery for BPH': 'Surgical indications and options for management of BPH were discussed. Benefits include an increase in Qmax, decrease in prostate volume, and improvement in symptom score. Risks including but not limited to bleeding, infection, bladder neck contracture, urethral stricture, injury to the lower urinary tract, incontinence, sexual dysfunction, and the need for additional procedures discussed.', 'Any discussion regarding kidney stone surgery': 'The patient has a stone burden requiring surgical intervention. Surgical options for stone management discussed. Risks including but not limited to infection, bleeding, stricture formation, urethral/bladder/ureteral/kidney injury, and injury to adjacent structures were explained.', 'Any discussion regarding surgery or a procedure': 'The risks, benefits, and alternatives of the proposed procedure were discussed with the patient at length and in detail. Possible complications including but not limited to pain, infection, bleeding, scar tissue formation, injury to adjacent structures, and the need for postoperative treatments including further surgical procedures were explained.'}

reference_summarize_jobs:
[['CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and Management of: Hypertension, coronary artery disease, hyperlipidemia, BPH, recurrent diverticulitis, back pain.

INTERVAL HISTORY:
Patient reports worsening back pain with sciatica. He has seen a surgeon named Dr. Nazarian who performed an MRI and has recommended fusion of S1 and L5 with laminectomies on L2, L3, L4, and L5. Patient states he has difficulty standing for more than a minute before his back becomes too tight. He also reports a hypertensive episode in January where his blood pressure measured 225/205 on a wrist cuff and 205/200 on a regular cuff. He called an ambulance, and his blood pressure gradually decreased to 190/90 and then 185. He consulted with his cardiologist who advised dietary changes. Patient has eliminated salt and sweets from his diet and reports steady weight loss. He also mentions having surgery on his right ring finger which "didn't go so good" and may need revision. Patient reports worsening urinary symptoms related to BPH.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
Hypertension
Coronary artery disease with "part of the bottom dead" and "multiple grafts"
Hyperlipidemia
Benign prostatic hyperplasia
Recurrent diverticulitis
Sciatica
Memory issues

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:
Surgery on right ring finger (recent)
Cardiac bypass grafting (date unknown)

ALLERGIES:
No known allergies
No known drug allergies

MEDICATIONS:
Tamsulosin (Flomax) for BPH
Meloxicam (as needed for pain)
Antihypertensive medications (specific names not mentioned)

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

Vitals:
Blood pressure: 116/not specified
Weight: Not specified but patient reports steady weight loss

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
General Appearance: no acute distress
Skin: intact, no rash or lesions
Head: normocephalic, atraumatic
Eyes: sclera non-icteric
Neck: supple
Respiratory: lungs clear to auscultation
Cardiovascular: normal S1 and S2
Extremities: no edema noted
Neurologic: alert and oriented, no gross focal neurologic deficits
Psychiatric: appropriate mood and affect

IMPRESSION/PLAN:
Chronic coronary artery disease
-- Patient reports part of the bottom of heart is "dead" with multiple grafts
-- Continue current medication
-- Aerobic exercise encouraged
-- Pharmacotherapy has been effective

Essential hypertension
-- Patient had severe hypertensive episode in January with BP 225/205
-- Has made dietary changes including eliminating salt and sweets
-- Reports steady weight loss
-- Continue current medication
-- Pharmacotherapy is effective
-- Aerobic exercise encouraged

Benign prostatic hyperplasia with urinary frequency
-- Patient reports symptoms are "a little bit worse"
-- Continue Flomax (tamsulosin) 0.4 mg capsule; Take 1 capsule (0.4 mg total) by mouth daily
-- Previously saw urologist Dr. Maggio who has since moved

Primary osteoarthritis of knee, unspecified laterality
-- Unchanged
-- Pharmacotherapy provides adequate relief of pain
-- Continue current medication
-- Meloxicam (MOBIC) 7.5 mg tablet; Take 1 tablet (7.5 mg total) by mouth 2 times a day as needed for pain
-- Metaxalone (SKELAXIN) 800 mg tablet; Take 1 tablet (800 mg total) by mouth 3 times a day

Gastroesophageal reflux disease, esophagitis presence not specified
-- NexIUM 40 mg capsule; Take 1 capsule (40 mg total) by mouth daily before breakfast

Bruised ribs
-- Patient encouraged to use his incentive spirometer once an hour until the pain has resolved
-- Can have an x-ray if desired

Lumbar spinal stenosis with sciatica
-- Patient reports worsening symptoms with difficulty standing for more than a minute
-- Has seen surgeon Dr. Nazarian who recommended fusion of S1 and L5 with laminectomies on L2-L5
-- Surgery is "imminent" according to patient
-- Continue pain management in interim

Status: Stable

Follow up: 1 year

High blood pressure evaluation and management

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:  
Peter Allain presents with a history of high blood pressure. He was previously taking Telmisartan for approximately one and a half years but was taken off the medication by a physician assistant after his primary care provider fell ill. Since then, Peter has attempted to manage his weight but reports that his blood pressure remained elevated. Recently, during a visit to urgent care for a sinus infection, his blood pressure was recorded at 170 mmHg. He was advised to follow up with a primary care provider concerning his blood pressure management. He reports completing antibiotic treatment, a nasal spray, and eye drops for his sinus infection from the urgent care visit.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  
Hypertension

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:  
No surgical history mentioned.

ALLERGIES:  
No known allergies  
No known drug allergies

MEDICATIONS:  
Formerly on Telmisartan; exact dosage unknown

FAMILY HISTORY:  
History of hypertension in father; possible hypertension in mother, but not confirmed.

SOCIAL HISTORY:  
Peter does not smoke. He had one alcoholic drink the previous day but does not drink regularly.

OCCUPATION:  
Not specified in the transcript

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:  
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

Vitals:  
Blood pressure noted to be high today, though specific reading not provided in transcript.

OBJECTIVE:  
Physical Examination:  
General Appearance: no acute distress  
Skin: intact, no rash or lesions  
Head: normocephalic, atraumatic  
Eyes: sclera non-icteric  
Neck: supple  
Respiratory: lungs clear to auscultation  
Cardiovascular: normal S1 and S2  
Gastrointestinal: abdomen soft, non-tender, non distended  
Musculoskeletal: normal ROM b/l upper and lower extremities  
Extremities: no edema noted  
Neurologic: alert and oriented, no gross focal neurologic deficits  
Psychiatric: appropriate mood and affect

IMPRESSION/PLAN:  
Annual physical/wellness  
-- Discuss plans for overall health maintenance including upcoming vaccinations and potential colonoscopy due to age.

Hypertension  
-- Reintroduced Telmisartan, now combined with Amlodipine, with instructions to take one pill daily. Prescribed a 30-day supply with two refills. Peter is to try this regimen for three days and return in one month to evaluate control of his blood pressure. Blood work will be conducted at this visit, and results will be discussed at the follow-up.

Status: Monitor Closely

Follow up: 1 month

reviewed_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and Management of: hypertension

INTERVAL HISTORY:
Patient presents for follow-up of hypertension. She reports having received the old shingles vaccine in 2015 and is inquiring about getting the new one. She has a colonoscopy consultation scheduled for 08/04/25. Patient reports having a pacemaker. She had a mammogram in January which was clear. Patient has been seeing an eye doctor and reports no changes with her glasses. She uses hearing aids which she reports are helping. Patient mentions having some swelling in one leg that is more pronounced than the other, though she can still walk and move around. She requires antibiotic prophylaxis before dental procedures and has an upcoming dental appointment on Thursday. Recent lab work shows cholesterol levels are good with LDL at 73, and liver and kidney function tests are normal. Blood count was normal.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
Hypertension
Atrial fibrillation requiring pacemaker
Venous insufficiency

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:
Pacemaker placement
Bilateral hip replacements

ALLERGIES:
No known allergies
No known drug allergies

MEDICATIONS:
Atorvastatin 40 mg daily
Telmisartan-hydrochlorothiazide
Metoprolol 25 mg
Eliquis 5 mg
Amoxicillin (for dental prophylaxis)

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

Vitals:
Blood pressure: 124/80

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
General Appearance: no acute distress
Skin: intact, no rash or lesions
Head: normocephalic, atraumatic
Eyes: sclera non-icteric
Neck: supple
Respiratory: lungs clear to auscultation
Cardiovascular: normal S1 and S2
Gastrointestinal: abdomen soft, non-tender, non distended
Musculoskeletal: normal ROM b/l upper and lower extremities
Extremities: mild swelling noted in one leg
Neurologic: alert and oriented, no gross focal neurologic deficits
Psychiatric: appropriate mood and affect

IMPRESSION/PLAN:
Hypertension
-- Blood pressure well controlled today at 124/80
-- Continue current medications
-- Will monitor at follow-up visits

Venous insufficiency
-- Patient reports one leg is more swollen than the other
-- No significant concerns at this time
-- Patient able to ambulate without difficulty

S/P TAVR
-- Doing well
-- Continues to follow with cardiologist

Atrial fibrillation
-- On anticoagulation with Eliquis 5 mg
-- Managed with pacemaker
-- Continue current management

Hyperlipidemia
-- LDL cholesterol well controlled at 73
-- Continue atorvastatin 40 mg daily

Preventive care
-- Mammogram completed in January with normal results
-- Dental care ongoing with antibiotic prophylaxis
-- Colonoscopy consultation scheduled for 08/04/25
-- Recommended new shingles vaccine after colonoscopy is completed

Status: Stable

Follow up: 3 months

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.

history_of_present_illness: Tairy Cabrera, a 37-year-old female, presents to establish care with a allege diagnosed of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) diagnosed in February 2024. She has been on hydroxychloroquine since May 2024. She states she was seen by a rheumatologist in Jersey City who recently retired in December. At that point in time according to her husband it was not completely clear if she truly had lupus. As per husband was translating for her while question was if she had a combination of lupus and possibly rheumatoid arthritis even though all the markers specifically associated with those 2 diseases were negative and she had a mildly positive ANA. She was placed on hydroxychloroquine and according to the patient she stated she felt well on it. Eventually she had become pregnant and she discontinued the medication. Unfortunately she lost her pregnancy and since then she restarted the medication but it seems to not be effective. She reports symptoms including palpitations, dizziness, numbness in hands and feet, generalized pain, sleep disruptions/poor, and a history of Raynaud's phenomenon. She reports multiple ER visits due to palpitations and severe fatigue. Peripheral blood tests in January 2024 revealed a positive ANA (1:80), WBC count of 4.5, hemoglobin 14.8 g/dL, hematocrit 44.4%, and platelet count 312. Absolute lymphocyte count was 2223 within normal limits. Urinalysis showed no protein or blood presence. The patient reports being treated for anxiety and is on Nadolol and Fluoxetine but states persistent symptoms, particularly pain and fatigue. Notably, she experienced the loss of a child due to pregnancy complications in September 2024. There is a noted familial history of similar symptoms in a cousin. Recent evaluations raise the question of fibromyalgia, supported by symptoms such as widespread musculoskeletal pain, sleep disturbances, and cognitive disturbances (brain fog), exacerbated by stress, diffuse discomfort when her child hugs her.In addition when she was young she was very flexible and she can currently touch her thumb to her forearms bilaterally. She has mild hyperextension's of her elbow. She can still touch the floor flat with her hands she has easy bruising and she has a history of heavy painful periods. She also has some dizziness from lying down to sitting up position or sitting up to standing she also has palpitations and anxiety. In addition she has diarrhea alternating with constipation.

plan:
Discontinue hydroxychloroquine as there was no difference of being on it or off of it.
I have requested that patient call the aqua therapy facility as she was given the information on her last visit. She states she will.
Discussed use of multivitamin and magnesium supplementation, which patient states she will try.
Emphasize the importance of continuing anxiety management with her primary care physician.
Return to clinic in six weeks.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.
reviewed_note:
DATE OF VISIT: 6/27/2025
PATIENT: Cabrera, Tairy
REFERRING PROVIDER: 

CHIEF COMPLAINT: Evaluation and management of an alleged diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Tairy Cabrera, a 37-year-old female, presents to establish care with a allege diagnosed of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) diagnosed in February 2024. She has been on hydroxychloroquine since May 2024. She states she was seen by a rheumatologist in Jersey City who recently retired in December. At that point in time according to her husband it was not completely clear if she truly had lupus. As per husband was translating for her while question was if she had a combination of lupus and possibly rheumatoid arthritis even though all the markers specifically associated with those 2 diseases were negative and she had a mildly positive ANA. She was placed on hydroxychloroquine and according to the patient she stated she felt well on it. Eventually she had become pregnant and she discontinued the medication. Unfortunately she lost her pregnancy and since then she restarted the medication but it seems to not be effective. She reports symptoms including palpitations, dizziness, numbness in hands and feet, generalized pain, sleep disruptions/poor, and a history of Raynaud's phenomenon. She reports multiple ER visits due to palpitations and severe fatigue. Peripheral blood tests in January 2024 revealed a positive ANA (1:80), WBC count of 4.5, hemoglobin 14.8 g/dL, hematocrit 44.4%, and platelet count 312. Absolute lymphocyte count was 2223 within normal limits. Urinalysis showed no protein or blood presence. The patient reports being treated for anxiety and is on Nadolol and Fluoxetine but states persistent symptoms, particularly pain and fatigue. Notably, she experienced the loss of a child due to pregnancy complications in September 2024. There is a noted familial history of similar symptoms in a cousin. Recent evaluations raise the question of fibromyalgia, supported by symptoms such as widespread musculoskeletal pain, sleep disturbances, and cognitive disturbances (brain fog), exacerbated by stress, diffuse discomfort when her child hugs her.In addition when she was young she was very flexible and she can currently touch her thumb to her forearms bilaterally. She has mild hyperextension's of her elbow. She can still touch the floor flat with her hands she has easy bruising and she has a history of heavy painful periods. She also has some dizziness from lying down to sitting up position or sitting up to standing she also has palpitations and anxiety. In addition she has diarrhea alternating with constipation.

INTERVAL HISTORY:
6/27/25: Patient reports she has been walking more for exercise. She has not tried aqua therapy yet despite having the information. Patient reports having an eye infection for several weeks that has not resolved despite antibiotic eye drops prescribed at an emergency room for conjunctivitis. She reports eye dryness and mouth dryness with persistent cough. The right eye appears red and is itchy, particularly bothersome at night. Patient denies any vision changes. No other new medical issues reported. Patient has not tried magnesium supplementation for muscle relaxation.

MEDICATIONS:
Inside         Drug         Script Date         Qty         Rfls         Instructions                               
FLUOXETINE HCL 20 MG CAPSULE         2/18/2025         15         0                                         
HYDROXYCHLOROQUINE 200 MG TAB         1/22/2025         60         0         TAKE 1 TABLET BY MOUTH IN THE MORNING AND IN THE EVENING                               
NADOLOL 20 MG TABLET         3/8/2025         30         0         TAKE ONE TABLET (20 MG) DAILY BY MOUTH INDICATIONS: HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE                               
Vitamin D3 50 mcg (2,000 unit) tablet         4/11/2025                   0

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, sclera erythematous, more on the left than right eye. Chest: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. Heart: Normal S1 S2, regular rate and rhythm. Ext: No edema. Skin: No skin rash. Musculoskeletal: No swelling noted in any of the joints in both the upper or lower extremities. Fibromyalgia trigger points 18 out of 18.

ASSESSMENT:
Positive ANA
Patient has a low positive ANA (1:80). All other rheumatological markers associated with a positive ANA came back negative. Protein/creatinine ratio was within normal limits. Urinalysis on repeat was negative. Based on comprehensive testing, as of now, there is insufficient evidence to support a definitive SLE diagnosis.

Fibromyalgia
Patient continues to have symptoms consistent with fibromyalgia. We have discontinued hydroxychloroquine, and patient has not noticed any difference in terms of being on the medication and being off the medication. Patient is reiterated treatment options for fibromyalgia including aqua therapy, Tai Chi, stress reduction techniques. Discussed again as previously noted in my notes discussed the medications for fibromyalgia (antidepressants, anti-anxiety medications, muscle relaxers, nerve medications) which can be given by her PCP. Emphasized importance of controlling anxiety as key to managing fibromyalgia symptoms.

Sclera erythematous
Unclear of etiology. Patient was given medications to treat, as she was told it was conjunctivitis by the ER, but she has not noticed any improvement. The patient has no issues with her vision. She states her vision is clear, but her right eye is more erythematous than her left. I will give her a referral to ophthalmology to have her eyes be evaluated.

PLAN:
Discontinue hydroxychloroquine as there was no difference of being on it or off of it.
I have requested that patient call the aqua therapy facility as she was given the information on her last visit. She states she will.
Discussed use of multivitamin and magnesium supplementation, which patient states she will try.
Emphasize the importance of continuing anxiety management with her primary care physician.
Return to clinic in six weeks.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.

You need to capture all medical information relevant to an oncologist. Write the note in formal language like an oncologist would, using medical terminology. I am going to give you a conversation to summarize into a note. Absolutely do not hallucinate any information and stick strictly to the transcript and do not get information from anywhere else. Do not put "the doctor" or "the transcript" or "the conversation" anywhere in the note. Do not hallucinate age and only include age if found in the transcript. Stay objective and academic and scientific. In the "Chief Complaint" section, write it verbatim. Leave History of Present Illness exactly as is. Write INTERVAL HISTORY in concise sentences like a rheumatologist would. Only include patient symptoms and any updates on their condition using formal and scientific medical language. Write dates in M/D/YY format. Do not hallucinate any lab, imaging, or pathology results and use the exact stated medical language. Write disease stages in roman numerals. Write all other numbers in number form. UPDATE THE LIST OF DIAGNOSES THAT IS THERE IN the ASSESSMENT based on the conversation. Output each diagnosis on a separate line. Do not add dashes or bullet points. Add any new diagnoses if significant. Beside each diagnosis, add a summarization of what was discussed with the patient and next steps in sentences. Do not delete any diagnoses. Add all pertinent lab results, imaging results, studies mentioned and pathology results to diagnoses. Be very detailed and comprehensive in summarizing discussion of diagnoses and treatment plans, patient education, treatment options, studies discussed, risks, differential diagnoses, in the pertinent diagnoses. Indicate if discussion was long. Indicate if family members were present. If a diagnosis is not discussed, leave it as is. Write "PLAN" in detailed sentences, with each sentence on a new line. Do not add a dash or bullet point before each sentence. If there are dictations in the transcript, extract the dictated sentences, put verbatim what is dictated into the correct sections.
Use the provided starting note and fill out the rest of it. Leave Review of Systems as is. For Disease History and Medications - output the sections exactly as written. For the Physical Examination, if no information is provided or exam dictated, put the default information from the template. Otherwise update the Physical Examination.
There are also some reference notes from the same doctor, focus on learning the language used, how each note is written, and formatting and structure of each section of the reference notes. Reference these notes when writing the new note if it is helpful. Absolutely do not hallucinate.
Do not use Markdown formatting. Do not prefix headings with "#" or any special characters.
Make sure the knowtex privacy/consent line is present in the output.

Are you ready?
[STARTING NOTE START]
CHIEF COMPLAINT: Evaluation and management of an alleged diagnosis of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Tairy Cabrera, a 37-year-old female, presents to establish care with a allege diagnosed of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) diagnosed in February 2024. She has been on hydroxychloroquine since May 2024. She states she was seen by a rheumatologist in Jersey City who recently retired in December. At that point in time according to her husband it was not completely clear if she truly had lupus. As per husband was translating for her while question was if she had a combination of lupus and possibly rheumatoid arthritis even though all the markers specifically associated with those 2 diseases were negative and she had a mildly positive ANA. She was placed on hydroxychloroquine and according to the patient she stated she felt well on it. Eventually she had become pregnant and she discontinued the medication. Unfortunately she lost her pregnancy and since then she restarted the medication but it seems to not be effective. She reports symptoms including palpitations, dizziness, numbness in hands and feet, generalized pain, sleep disruptions/poor, and a history of Raynaud's phenomenon. She reports multiple ER visits due to palpitations and severe fatigue. Peripheral blood tests in January 2024 revealed a positive ANA (1:80), WBC count of 4.5, hemoglobin 14.8 g/dL, hematocrit 44.4%, and platelet count 312. Absolute lymphocyte count was 2223 within normal limits. Urinalysis showed no protein or blood presence. The patient reports being treated for anxiety and is on Nadolol and Fluoxetine but states persistent symptoms, particularly pain and fatigue. Notably, she experienced the loss of a child due to pregnancy complications in September 2024. There is a noted familial history of similar symptoms in a cousin. Recent evaluations raise the question of fibromyalgia, supported by symptoms such as widespread musculoskeletal pain, sleep disturbances, and cognitive disturbances (brain fog), exacerbated by stress, diffuse discomfort when her child hugs her.In addition when she was young she was very flexible and she can currently touch her thumb to her forearms bilaterally. She has mild hyperextension's of her elbow. She can still touch the floor flat with her hands she has easy bruising and she has a history of heavy painful periods. She also has some dizziness from lying down to sitting up position or sitting up to standing she also has palpitations and anxiety. In addition she has diarrhea alternating with constipation.

INTERVAL HISTORY:
2025-6-27:

MEDICATIONS:
Inside         Drug         Script Date         Qty         Rfls         Instructions                               FLUOXETINE HCL 20 MG CAPSULE         2/18/2025         15         0                                         HYDROXYCHLOROQUINE 200 MG TAB         1/22/2025         60         0         TAKE 1 TABLET BY MOUTH IN THE MORNING AND IN THE EVENING                               NADOLOL 20 MG TABLET         3/8/2025         30         0         TAKE ONE TABLET (20 MG) DAILY BY MOUTH INDICATIONS: HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE                               Vitamin D3 50 mcg (2,000 unit) tablet         4/11/2025                   0

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. HEENT:PERRLA,EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear. Nodes: No peripheral adenopathy. Chest: Clear bilaterally. Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat.
Abd: Soft, +BS, non tender and non distended, no masses, no organomegaly. Ext: No edema. Skin: no rash. Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact. Musculoskeletal: Normal gait.

ASSESSMENT:
Positive ANAPatient has a low positive ANA (1:80). All other rheumatological markers associated with a positive ANA came back negative. Protein/creatinine ratio was within normal limits. Urinalysis showed protein and blood, but patient confirmed she was menstruating when sample was collected. Will repeat urinalysis to confirm absence of blood. Based on comprehensive testing, there is insufficient evidence to support a definitive SLE diagnosis. Long discussion with patient and husband regarding test results and clinical presentation.FibromyalgiaPatient continues to have symptoms consistent with fibromyalgia. Discussed that hydroxychloroquine is not typically used for fibromyalgia, though some studies suggest it may help with osteoarthritic pain. Recommended patient consider stopping hydroxychloroquine to determine if there is any difference in symptoms on or off the medication. Patient is agreeable to this trial. Reiterated treatment options for fibromyalgia including aqua therapy, Tai Chi, and stress reduction techniques. Discussed that medications for fibromyalgia (antidepressants, anti-anxiety medications, muscle relaxers, and nerve medications) can be given by her PCP. Emphasized importance of controlling anxiety as key to managing fibromyalgia symptoms.

PLAN:

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.
[STARTING NOTE END]

PATIENT:

CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Recurrent episodes of hematuria (blood in urine)

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
The patient is a male with a history of urethral cancer who has been experiencing recurrent episodes of hematuria. Recently, he underwent radiation around 12 to 15 years ago, and this is suspected to be contributing to his current urinary problems. His urologist had advised him to frequently hydrate and empty his bladder to prevent clot formation. He mentioned a past upper endoscopy procedure due to what was suspected might be a tumor. A biopsy was done, but there was no definite mention of tumor detection. He is scheduled to complete the third cycle of his chemotherapy treatments by August 31st, with another treatment response scan planned for early September to evaluate his liver tumors' response to his treatment. 

INTERVAL HISTORY:
The blood in his urine previously stopped, but recurred again on the day of this visit. He reported feeling tired and had been experiencing nausea, though he noted that his oral condition had improved with him now being able to brush his teeth without the occurrence of blood blisters. 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
Past history of urethral cancer, currently under chemotherapy treatment.

ALLERGIES:
No known allergies
No known drug allergies

MEDICATIONS:
Current chemotherapy medication names have not been specified.

History unclear.

Not done during this visit.

Complete Blood Count (CBC) - Date unspecified: Hemoglobin levels decreased from 11.8 to 11.3, now at 10.

IMAGING RESULTS:
No imaging results reported.

IMPRESSION:
1. Urethral cancer
2. Radiation induced urinary problems (suspected)

PLAN:
1. Continue chemotherapy treatments
2. Reschedule urologist consult
3. First week of September: Treatment response scan for liver tumors.
4. Follow up visit in four weeks (around September 8, 2023) with possible continuation of injections, dependent on patient's condition.

DISCUSSION:
The diagnosis, treatment plan, recent symptoms, and future interventions were discussed with the patient, with a key focus on the significance of the upcoming treatment response scan and the effect of the ongoing chemotherapy treatments on his liver tumors. Emphasis was also given on the possibility that his prior radiation treatments could now be leading to his urinary problems, leading to the recurrent hematuria.

She also has some dizziness from lying down to sitting up position or sitting up to standing she also has palpitations and anxiety. In addition she has diarrhea alternating with constipation.

6/27/25: Patient reports she has been walking more for exercise. She has not tried aqua therapy yet despite having the information. Patient reports having an eye infection for several weeks that has not resolved despite antibiotic eye drops prescribed at an emergency room for conjunctivitis. She reports eye dryness and mouth dryness with persistent cough. The right eye appears red and is itchy, particularly bothersome at night. Patient denies any vision changes. No other new medical issues reported. Patient has not tried magnesium supplementation for muscle relaxation.

MEDICATIONS:
Inside         Drug         Script Date         Qty         Rfls         Instructions                               
FLUOXETINE HCL 20 MG CAPSULE         2/18/2025         15         0                                         
HYDROXYCHLOROQUINE 200 MG TAB         1/22/2025         60         0         TAKE 1 TABLET BY MOUTH IN THE MORNING AND IN THE EVENING                               
NADOLOL 20 MG TABLET         3/8/2025         30         0         TAKE ONE TABLET (20 MG) DAILY BY MOUTH INDICATIONS: HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE                               
Vitamin D3 50 mcg (2,000 unit) tablet         4/11/2025                   0

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, sclera erythematous, more on the left than right eye. Chest: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. Heart: Normal S1 S2, regular rate and rhythm. Ext: No edema. Skin: No skin rash. Musculoskeletal: No swelling noted in any of the joints in both the upper or lower extremities. Fibromyalgia trigger points 18 out of 18.

ASSESSMENT:
Positive ANA
Patient has a low positive ANA (1:80). All other rheumatological markers associated with a positive ANA came back negative. Protein/creatinine ratio was within normal limits. Urinalysis on repeat was negative. Based on comprehensive testing, as of now, there is insufficient evidence to support a definitive SLE diagnosis.

Fibromyalgia
Patient continues to have symptoms consistent with fibromyalgia. We have discontinued hydroxychloroquine, and patient has not noticed any difference in terms of being on the medication and being off the medication. Patient is reiterated treatment options for fibromyalgia including aqua therapy, Tai Chi, stress reduction techniques. Discussed again as previously noted in my notes discussed the medications for fibromyalgia (antidepressants, anti-anxiety medications, muscle relaxers, nerve medications) which can be given by her PCP. Emphasized importance of controlling anxiety as key to managing fibromyalgia symptoms.

Sclera erythematous
Unclear of etiology. Patient was given medications to treat, as she was told it was conjunctivitis by the ER, but she has not noticed any improvement. The patient has no issues with her vision. She states her vision is clear, but her right eye is more erythematous than her left. I will give her a referral to ophthalmology to have her eyes be evaluated.

PLAN:
Discontinue hydroxychloroquine as there was no difference of being on it or off of it.
I have requested that patient call the aqua therapy facility as she was given the information on her last visit. She states she will.
Discussed use of multivitamin and magnesium supplementation, which patient states she will try.
Emphasize the importance of continuing anxiety management with her primary care physician.
Return to clinic in six weeks.

reviewed_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and Management of triglyceride levels. Type 2 diabetes

INTERVAL HISTORY:
Patient reports he went off his diet recently and acknowledges this has affected his blood sugar control. He recently had cataract surgery on his right eye last week using the laser method. He states it went well but still feels like there's something in his eye, though was told this sensation would resolve over the six-week healing period. Patient reports that weight loss medication has not been effective, stating he hasn't lost "even a pound." He also reports that his erectile dysfunction medication is not working. Patient is walking regularly for exercise and has encouraged his partner Joni to join him. Recent lab results show cholesterol at 131, LDL at 58, blood sugar at 130, good kidney function, and A1c at 7.2, which is higher than previous readings. Patient recently had pre-surgical cardiac clearance with EKG for his cataract procedure. He has not yet completed his colonoscopy but plans to schedule it.

Cataracts
