 REFERRING PROVIDER: Dr. Shabazz

CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Right breast cancer and osteopenia 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Patient was initially diagnosed with right breast cancer in 2017. Her primary physician then was Dr. Eliazo who transitioned her care to me due to insurance change. The breast abnormality was detected during a routine mammogram in 2017, and Dr. Gomina performed the lumpectomy twice in March and April of the same year as the first surgery did not yield clear margins. 
The tumor was measured to be 0.9 cm on pathology, with grade 2. It was found to be estrogen receptor positive (100%), progesterone receptor negative (0%), and HER2-negative. The lymph nodes were reported negative. 

Post-surgery, the patient underwent radiation treatment only and was put on a five-year course of Letrozole which completed in 2022. She currently undergoes mammograms every six months. Her recent mammogram was done in January 2024.

The patient also has osteopenia. She receives yearly Reclast infusions for managing this, with the last infusion given in June. Her DEXA scan in January 2024 indicated a persistent low bone mass. 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
Historic right breast cancer
Osteopenia

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:
Right breast lumpectomy twice in March and April 2017

ALLERGIES:
No known allergies
No known drug allergies

MEDICATIONS:
None noted

FAMILY HISTORY:
Mother: Deceased from diabetes, hypertension, CHF
Father: Deceased from COPD, diabetes, possible hypertension
Two sons, both reported as healthy

TOBACCO USE AND CESSATION COUNSELING:
Patient denies any smoking or illicit drug use. Reports occasional social drinking.

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Patient is not married but has a significant other. 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
A 14 point review of system was negative with the exception of what is mentioned in the HPI

OBJECTIVE:
ECOG 0: Fully active, able to carry on all predisease performance without restriction
Physical Examination:
Constitutional Alert, cooperative, oriented. Mood and affect appropriate. Appears close to chronological age. Well nourished. Well developed.
Head Normocephalic; no scars.
Eyes Conjunctivae and sclerae are clear and without icterus. Pupils are reactive and equal.
ENMT Sinuses are nontender. No oral exudates, ulcers, masses, thrush or mucositis. Oropharynx clear. Tongue normal.
Neck Supple without masses or thyromegaly. No jugular venous distension.
Hematologic/Lymphatic No petechiae or purpura. No tender or palpable lymph nodes in the cervical, supraclavicular, axillary or inguinal area.
Respiratory Lungs are clear to auscultation without rhonchi or wheezing.
Cardiovascular Regular rate and rhythm of heart without murmurs, gallops or rubs.
Chest Chest is symmetric without chest wall deformities.
Abdomen Non-tender, non-distended, no masses, ascites or hepatosplenomegaly. Good bowel sounds. No guarding or rebound tenderness. No pulsatile masses.
Back/Spine No kyphosis, scoliosis, compression fractures. Non-tender to palpation.
Musculoskeletal No tenderness or swelling, normal range of motion without obvious weakness.
Extremities No visible deformities, no cyanosis, clubbing or edema. Pulses 4+ and equal bilaterally.
Integumentary No rashes, scars, or lesions suggestive of malignancy.
Neurologic No sensory or motor deficits, normal cerebellar function, normal gait, cranial nerves intact.
Psychiatric Alert and oriented times three. Coherent speech. Verbalizes understanding of our discussions today.


LABORATORY RESULTS:
Calcium levels measured on 04-11-2024 were at the lower edge of normal (9.7)

IMAGING RESULTS:
Last mammogram conducted on 01-2024 reported unremarkable

IMPRESSION:
1. History of right breast cancer, estrogen receptor-positive (100%), progesterone receptor-negative, HER2-negative

DISCUSSION:
Discussed the management of low bone mass osteopenia and the necessary lifestyle modifications that the patient may need. Recommended to replace Reclast infusions with Prolia injections which are less stressful on the kidneys. Also advised the patient on the importance of taking a combination of calcium and vitamin D for better absorption. The patient agreed to try Prolia and the calcium/vitamin D combination. 

PLAN:
1. Change bone management strategy to Prolia injections from Reclast infusions, to be started around July
2. Patient to start a combination of calcium and vitamin D supplement
3. Continue monitoring bone mass via DEXA scan 
4. Continue regular mammograms 
5. Review and manage patient's condition during next appointment, scheduled in July before the 4th 

 [REFERENCE NOTE1 END]

reference_summarize_jobs:
[["stephanie russell is a female presenting for follow-up for decreased blood flow to the right areola following a previous procedure. The patient was observed with a heart rate of 122 bpm, blood pressure of 72/55 mmHg initially with a wrist cuff, which improved to 100/55 mmHg with a manual cuff, indicating weak pulses and difficulty in manual heart rate detection. An IV bolus of lactated Ringer's solution was initiated via a 22-gauge needle in the left antecubital fossa. The patient displayed symptoms consistent with third spacing, leading to fluid loss from blood vessels. There was noted concern regarding increased bruising in the area surrounding the right areola. Plastic surgery intervention is considered to alleviate stress and enhance blood flow.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: None
PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: None
ALLERGIES: None
CURRENT MEDICATIONS: None

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
The examination revealed decreased blood flow to the right areola, with increased bruising observed in the surrounding area.

Impression:
Decreased blood flow to the right areola with increased bruising, likely due to postoperative changes.

Treatment plan:
Removal of stitches around the nipple area to relieve stress and improve blood flow. Continuous monitoring of blood flow through the provided application and tools to track changes. The patient was advised to refrain from strenuous activities and to engage in controlled movement to enhance recovery and prevent exacerbation of symptoms. Encouragement was given to utilize breathing exercises and gradual ambulation to aid in recovery. The plan includes optimizing hydration status and monitoring for third spacing effects.", 0]]
reviewed_note:
PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIAN: Dr. Brunst (previously); currently seen at Perlman Clinic in Santee

CLINICAL SUMMARY:
80M with multiple squamous cell and basal cell carcinomas requiring ongoing management.
- Patient has history of numerous skin cancers over several years treated by Dr. Richards (dermatologist)
- [Date unknown] Multiple prior surgical excisions with difficult healing and bleeding complications due to blood thinner use
- [Date unknown] Began radiation therapy for some lesions with Dr. Shimuzu after experiencing severe pain during procedures
- [03/2025] Multiple biopsies showing: chest (squamous cell), right forearm (basal cell), right radial dorsal hand (basal cell), right ulnar dorsal hand (squamous cell in situ), right thigh (squamous cell), left upper back (basal cell)
- [Date unknown] Completed radiation to lesion on arm one month ago, still healing
- [Date unknown] Previously evaluated by Dr. Bolin for possible immunotherapy but was not deemed appropriate at that time
- [08/06/2025] Underwent blue light therapy, skin currently inflamed
- [Recent] Five new biopsies, all reportedly squamous cell carcinomas
- Current concerning lesion on left lower leg, ulcerated, present for approximately 6 months, not amenable to radiation per Dr. Shimuzu (who will not treat below elbow or knee)

ADDITIONAL PAST MEDICAL/SURGICAL HISTORY INFORMATION:
Past medical history:
- Heart failure diagnosed 2017, has defibrillator
- Diabetes mellitus diagnosed 2010
- Diabetic neuropathy for approximately 20 years
- Three hospitalizations since 2017 for cardiac issues
- Fall with head injury two years ago, treated at Sharp

Past surgical history:
- Defibrillator placement 2017

SOCIAL HISTORY:
- Lives in Lakeside
- Never smoker
- Drinks two glasses of wine daily
- Lives in a vineyard

FAMILY HISTORY:
- Parents died of "weak hearts"
- Brother (7 years younger) had heart transplant
- No family history of cancer

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
12 point review of systems is reported as stable or normal unless noted in clinical summary or interval history.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
ECOG 0
GEN - Well developed, well nourished man in no distress.
HEENT - sclerae anicteric, mucous membranes moist, no oral lesions
CV - regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs
PULM - clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi
BREAST - 
ABD - soft, non tender, non distended, active bowel sounds, no masses, no hepatosplenomegaly
EXT - warm, well perfused, no edema. Ulcerated lesion on left lower leg. Multiple lesions on arms.
LYMPH - no palpable adenopathy in the cervical, supraclavicular, axillary, or inguinal regions
NEURO - no gross focal deficits
SKIN - Facial skin inflamed from recent blue light therapy. Multiple seborrheic keratoses on back. Evidence of prior radiation treatment on right chest with hair loss and mild erythema.

ASSESSMENT:
Multiple squamous cell carcinomas and basal cell carcinomas
Patient has extensive history of skin cancers treated with various modalities including surgical excision and radiation therapy. Currently has a concerning ulcerated squamous cell carcinoma on left lower leg that is not amenable to radiation per Dr. Shimuzu who will not treat below the knee. Patient has had difficulty with surgical excisions due to being on blood thinners for heart failure and experiencing excessive bleeding and poor healing. Recently started on Acitretin but has not begun taking it due to concerns about alcohol interaction. Recently underwent blue light therapy with significant skin inflammation. Discussed potential for immunotherapy if surgical options are exhausted, with expected 60-70% response rate for squamous cell carcinomas but slower response for basal cell carcinomas. Reviewed potential side effects including skin issues, fatigue, thyroid dysfunction, and rare but serious complications like pneumonitis.

Heart failure
Diagnosed in 2017, has defibrillator in place. Currently on Entresto and blood thinners. Followed by Dr. Chang at Scripps.

Diabetes mellitus
Diagnosed in 2010, complicated by neuropathy. Currently managed with Mounjaro and Farxiga (recommended by cardiologist).

RECOMMENDATION/PLAN:
Will contact Dr. Richards to discuss surgical options for the left lower leg lesion.
If surgery is not an option, will proceed with immunotherapy which would be administered every 3 weeks for at least one year.
Immunotherapy would likely address multiple lesions simultaneously.
No anticipated interactions between immunotherapy and current cardiac medications.
Patient should establish regular follow-up with primary care physician given multiple medical conditions.
Patient to continue with current dermatologic care including blue light therapy and consideration of Acitretin.

It is a pleasure to take care of Mr. Grimm.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.

Diabetes mellitus
Diagnosed in 2010, complicated by neuropathy. Currently managed with Mounjaro and Farxiga (recommended by cardiologist).

RECOMMENDATION/PLAN:
Will contact Dr. Richards to discuss surgical options for the left lower leg lesion.
If surgery is not an option, will proceed with immunotherapy which would be administered every 3 weeks for at least one year.
Immunotherapy would likely address multiple lesions simultaneously.
No anticipated interactions between immunotherapy and current cardiac medications.
Patient should establish regular follow-up with primary care physician given multiple medical conditions.
Patient to continue with current dermatologic care including blue light therapy and consideration of Acitretin.

It is a pleasure to take care of Mr. Grimm.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.

[{'content': 'You are a doctor named:Dr.KristenRice writing a visit note for patient:Grimm, Ray W. You need to capture as much medical information as possible in a logical way. Write the note in formal language like an oncologist would, using medical terminology. I am going to give you a conversation to summarize into a note. Absolutely do not hallucinate any information and stick strictly to the transcript and do not get information from anywhere else. Do not put "the doctor" or "the transcript" or "the conversation" anywhere in the note. Do not hallucinate age and only include age if found in the transcript. Stay objective and scientific. In "PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIAN" just write the name of the primary care physician if mentioned, otherwise leave this blank.  Write CLINICAL SUMMARY in a concise, chronological, clearly organized way following the same style and formatting as in the following example:
80 [Sex] with [chief concern/primary problem and brief history of present illness].
- Provide a chronological recap of key lab/imaging results, and any significant milestones or referrals.
- Use the notation “[MM/DD/YY]” to introduce each milestone or test result.
- Summarize relevant details from procedures or consultations with other providers (e.g., endoscopy findings, pathology reports).
- Mention any major additional findings or next steps (e.g., referred to oncology, proposed treatments).

Separate any social history into SOCIAL HISTORY. Separate any family history into FAMILY HISTORY. Leave Review of Systems as is. For the Physical Examination, if no information is provided or exam dictated, put the default information from the template. Otherwise update the Physical Examination with the verbalized examination findings. Separate diagnoses (including all disease staging and scores) into a list in "ASSESSMENT." Put each diagnosis in a new line. Do not add dashes or bullet points. Put all medical decision making into ASSESSMENT. Next to each diagnosis, add a comprehensive summary of discussion of the diagnosis and next steps. Add pertinent lab results, imaging results, studies, and pathology results to diagnoses. Put any discussion of diagnosis education, differentials, treatment options, risks, indications, in the pertinent diagnosis. Do not leave out any details around diagnosis discussion. Write "RECOMMENDATION/PLAN" in sentences with each sentence on a new line. At the end, write "It is a pleasure to take care of Mr. or Ms. (patient's last name).
Use the provided starting note and fill out the rest of it. Only output the generated note and nothing else. If there are dictations in the transcript, extract the dictated sentences, write verbatim what is dictated into the correct sections. If "Clinical Summary" is dictated, please insert that dictation portion verbatim into "CLINICAL SUMMARY" with the formatting noted above. If "Impression" is dictated please insert that dictation portion verbatim into "Assessment." If there is already information in a section, do not overwrite the old information, but update or append to the section the new information. Do not repeat information or contradict information.  
There are also some reference notes from the same doctor, focus on learning the language used, how each note is written, and formatting and structure of each section of the reference notes. Reference these notes when writing the new note if it is helpful. Absolutely do not hallucinate.

Do not use Markdown formatting. Do not prefix headings with "#" or any special characters.
Make sure the knowtex privacy/consent line is present in the output.

 stephanie russell is a female presenting for follow-up for decreased blood flow to the right areola following a previous procedure. The patient was observed with a heart rate of 122 bpm, blood pressure of 72/55 mmHg initially with a wrist cuff, which improved to 100/55 mmHg with a manual cuff, indicating weak pulses and difficulty in manual heart rate detection. An IV bolus of lactated Ringer's solution was initiated via a 22-gauge needle in the left antecubital fossa. Plastic surgery intervention is considered to alleviate stress and enhance blood flow.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: None
PAST SURGICAL HISTORY: None
ALLERGIES: None

The examination revealed decreased blood flow to the right areola, with increased bruising observed in the surrounding area.

Decreased blood flow to the right areola with increased bruising, likely due to postoperative changes.

Removal of stitches around the nipple area to relieve stress and improve blood flow. Continuous monitoring of blood flow through the provided application and tools to track changes. The patient was advised to refrain from strenuous activities and to engage in controlled movement to enhance recovery and prevent exacerbation of symptoms. Encouragement was given to utilize breathing exercises and gradual ambulation to aid in recovery. The plan includes optimizing hydration status and monitoring for third spacing effects.

summarize_job_log.1:response:
Message(id='msg_01SV34x9Th4Ut1hGVrE7GjPc', content=[TextBlock(citations=None, text='PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIAN: Dr. Brunst (previously); currently seen at Perlman Clinic in Santee

CLINICAL SUMMARY:
80M with multiple squamous cell and basal cell carcinomas requiring ongoing management.
- Patient has history of numerous skin cancers over several years treated by Dr. Richards (dermatologist)
- [Date unknown] Multiple prior surgical excisions with difficult healing and bleeding complications due to blood thinner use
- [Date unknown] Began radiation therapy for some lesions with Dr. Shimuzu after experiencing severe pain during procedures
- [03/2025] Multiple biopsies showing: chest (squamous cell), right forearm (basal cell), right radial dorsal hand (basal cell), right ulnar dorsal hand (squamous cell in situ), right thigh (squamous cell), left upper back (basal cell)
- [Date unknown] Completed radiation to lesion on arm one month ago, still healing
- [Date unknown] Previously evaluated by Dr. Bolin for possible immunotherapy but was not deemed appropriate at that time
- [08/06/2025] Underwent blue light therapy, skin currently inflamed
- [Recent] Five new biopsies, all reportedly squamous cell carcinomas
- Current concerning lesion on left lower leg, ulcerated, present for approximately 6 months, not amenable to radiation per Dr. Shimuzu (who will not treat below elbow or knee)

ADDITIONAL PAST MEDICAL/SURGICAL HISTORY INFORMATION:
Past medical history:
- Heart failure diagnosed 2017, has defibrillator
- Diabetes mellitus diagnosed 2010
- Diabetic neuropathy for approximately 20 years
- Three hospitalizations since 2017 for cardiac issues
- Fall with head injury two years ago, treated at Sharp

Past surgical history:
- Defibrillator placement 2017

SOCIAL HISTORY:
- Lives in Lakeside
- Never smoker
- Drinks two glasses of wine daily
- Lives in a vineyard

FAMILY HISTORY:
- Parents died of "weak hearts"
- Brother (7 years younger) had heart transplant
- No family history of cancer

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
12 point review of systems is reported as stable or normal unless noted in clinical summary or interval history.

PHYSICAL EXAM:
ECOG 0
GEN - Well developed, well nourished man in no distress.
HEENT - sclerae anicteric, mucous membranes moist, no oral lesions
CV - regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs
PULM - clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi
BREAST - 
ABD - soft, non tender, non distended, active bowel sounds, no masses, no hepatosplenomegaly
EXT - warm, well perfused, no edema. Ulcerated lesion on left lower leg. Multiple lesions on arms.
LYMPH - no palpable adenopathy in the cervical, supraclavicular, axillary, or inguinal regions
NEURO - no gross focal deficits
SKIN - Facial skin inflamed from recent blue light therapy. Multiple seborrheic keratoses on back. Evidence of prior radiation treatment on right chest with hair loss and mild erythema.

ASSESSMENT:
Multiple squamous cell carcinomas and basal cell carcinomas
Patient has extensive history of skin cancers treated with various modalities including surgical excision and radiation therapy. Currently has a concerning ulcerated squamous cell carcinoma on left lower leg that is not amenable to radiation per Dr. Shimuzu who will not treat below the knee. Patient has had difficulty with surgical excisions due to being on blood thinners for heart failure and experiencing excessive bleeding and poor healing. Recently started on Acitretin but has not begun taking it due to concerns about alcohol interaction. Recently underwent blue light therapy with significant skin inflammation. Discussed potential for immunotherapy if surgical options are exhausted, with expected 60-70% response rate for squamous cell carcinomas but slower response for basal cell carcinomas. Reviewed potential side effects including skin issues, fatigue, thyroid dysfunction, and rare but serious complications like pneumonitis.

Heart failure
Diagnosed in 2017, has defibrillator in place. Currently on Entresto and blood thinners. Followed by Dr. Chang at Scripps.

Diabetes mellitus
Diagnosed in 2010, complicated by neuropathy. Currently managed with Mounjaro and Farxiga (recommended by cardiologist).

RECOMMENDATION/PLAN:
Will contact Dr. Richards to discuss surgical options for the left lower leg lesion.
If surgery is not an option, will proceed with immunotherapy which would be administered every 3 weeks for at least one year.
Immunotherapy would likely address multiple lesions simultaneously.
No anticipated interactions between immunotherapy and current cardiac medications.
Patient should establish regular follow-up with primary care physician given multiple medical conditions.
Patient to continue with current dermatologic care including blue light therapy and consideration of Acitretin.

It is a pleasure to take care of Mr. Grimm.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.', type='text')], model='claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219', role='assistant', stop_reason='end_turn', stop_sequence=None, type='message', usage=Usage(cache_creation_input_tokens=0, cache_read_input_tokens=0, input_tokens=6811, output_tokens=1208, service_tier='standard'))

history_of_present_illness: Eric Amin is a 24-year-old male presenting for evaluation of low testosterone symptoms. He reports experiencing low energy, fatigue, and feeling sluggish despite getting 8 hours of sleep and maintaining good sleep hygiene with reduced screen time before bed. He also complains of decreased libido and difficulty maintaining erections. The patient has a history of thyroid abnormalities for which he has been taking thyroid medication for approximately 7 years. He states that he initially attributed his symptoms to thyroid issues but decided to get his testosterone checked out of curiosity. Recent lab work showed a testosterone level of 2.95, which is considered low for his age. His TSH is currently elevated at 4.9 with T4 at 1.89. He reports the TSH elevation may be related to switching between generic and brand name thyroid medication. The patient maintains a good diet and sleep habits.
coding_information:
VISIT TYPE: Outpatient 
NEW OR FOLLOW-UP: New 
Complexity:
DIAGNOSIS: Hypogonadism, acute; Hypothyroidism, chronic; Erectile dysfunction, acute
ONSET: Acute for Hypogonadism and Erectile Dysfunction and Chronic for Hypothyroidism
STATUS: Unstable 
COMPLEXITY: MODERATE COMPLEXITY
Data:
IDENTIFIED CATEGORY 1: TEST and DOCUMENTS
1. TEST: Testosterone, TSH, T4 reports were reviewed.
2. TEST: Comprehensive hormone panel including total and free testosterone, sex hormone binding globulin, LH, FSH, estradiol, and prolactin was ordered.
IDENTIFIED CATEGORY 3: DISCUSSION OF MANAGEMENT OR TEST INTERPRETATION
1. DISCUSSION: Decision to obtain comprehensive hormone panel and discuss treatment options.
DATA REVIEWED AND/OR ANALYZED: MODERATE
Risk:
MODERATE RISK
1. DECISION: Testing and further evaluation of testosterone level, potential Clomid therapy, reassess erectile dysfunction after hormone evaluation
REASON: Prescription Drug Management
plan:
1. Hypogonadism, acute - Testosterone level is low at 2.95 for a 24-year-old male. Will obtain comprehensive hormone panel including total and free testosterone, sex hormone binding globulin, LH, FSH, estradiol, and prolactin. Patient instructed to complete testing before 9 AM due to circadian rhythm of testosterone. Will consider Clomid therapy rather than direct testosterone supplementation given patient's young age and potential fertility concerns.

2. Hypothyroidism, chronic - Patient has been on thyroid medication for 7 years. Current TSH elevated at 4.9 with T4 at 1.89. Elevation may be related to switching between generic and brand medication. Will continue current management.

3. Erectile dysfunction, acute - Patient reports difficulty maintaining erections. Will reassess after hormone evaluation is complete.

Follow-up appointment scheduled in 1-2 weeks to review laboratory results and discuss treatment options.

Recent lab work showed a testosterone level of 2.95, which is considered low for his age. His TSH is currently elevated at 4.9 with T4 at 1.89. He reports the TSH elevation may be related to switching between generic and brand name thyroid medication. The patient maintains a good diet and sleep habits.

Physical Exam:
Genitourinary: Testicles normal on examination.

Laboratory Results:
Testosterone: 2.95
TSH: 4.9
T4: 1.89
Creatinine: 1.1
GFR: 94
Cholesterol: 177
A1C: 5.5

Imaging Results:

Procedure:

Plan:
1. Hypogonadism, acute - Testosterone level is low at 2.95 for a 24-year-old male. Will obtain comprehensive hormone panel including total and free testosterone, sex hormone binding globulin, LH, FSH, estradiol, and prolactin. Patient instructed to complete testing before 9 AM due to circadian rhythm of testosterone. Will consider Clomid therapy rather than direct testosterone supplementation given patient's young age and potential fertility concerns.

2. Hypothyroidism, chronic - Patient has been on thyroid medication for 7 years. Current TSH elevated at 4.9 with T4 at 1.89. Elevation may be related to switching between generic and brand medication. Will continue current management.

3. Erectile dysfunction, acute - Patient reports difficulty maintaining erections. Will reassess after hormone evaluation is complete.

Follow-up appointment scheduled in 1-2 weeks to review laboratory results and discuss treatment options.

[{'content': 'You are a doctor named:Dr.Berman writing a visit note for patient:Amin, Eric. You need to capture as much medical information as possible in a logical way. Do not include headers or similar artificial headings. Start directly with the visit note format.', 'role': 'system'}, {'content': 'You are a urologist named:Dr.Berman writing a visit note for patient:Amin, Eric. The date of appointment is 2025-6-10, use this date when required in the note and note the year. You need to capture all medical information relevant to a urologist. This is a new patient visit. Write the note in formal language like a urologist would, using medical terminology. I am going to give you a conversation to summarize into a note. Absolutely do not hallucinate any information and stick strictly to the transcript and do not get information from anywhere else. Do not put "the doctor" or "the transcript" or "the conversation" anywhere in the note. Do not hallucinate age and only include age if found in the transcript. Stay objective and scientific. In "HPI" put all the patient's symptoms, relevant past medical history, current medications, relevant family history, and any dates mentioned. Because this is a new patient visit, be sure to be comprehensive and detailed in HPI. Do not misspell medication names. Write dates in M/D/YY format.  Do not include any medical decision making, planning, or discussion in the HPI. In "Physical Exam" put any verbalized physical examination findings from the transcript. If there are no verbalized physical examination findings, leave this section blank. In "Laboratory Results" Put any discussed lab results from the transcript using the exact stated numbers. Do not hallucinate any lab results and use the exact stated medical language. If there are no verbalized lab results, leave this section blank. In "Imaging Results" put any reviewed imaging results from the transcript using exact stated medical languaged and numbers. If there are no verbalized imaging results, leave this section blank. For Procedure, if the patient is a female undergoing cytoscopy, use the "Female Cytoscopy Template" and remove "Male Cytoscopy Template" from the note. If the patient is a Male undergoing cytoscopy, use the "Male Cytoscopy Template" and remove "Female Cytoscopy Template" from the note. Fill in the *** sections of the Procedure with the dictated findings. If there is no Cystoscopy or procedure mentioned, leave this section blank. In Plan, create a numbered list with medical diagnoses, and next to each diagnosis, put if it is stable, chronic, worsening, or acute. Write next steps in sentences for that diagnosis. Each diagnosis should be linked to a disease. Keep each numbered point concise. Put followup under a diagnosis, do not create a separate number for it.
Use the provided starting note and fill out the rest of it. Only output the generated note and nothing else.
There are also some reference notes from the same doctor; focus on learning the language used, how each note is written, and formatting and structure of each section of the reference notes. Reference these notes when writing the new note if it is helpful. Absolutely do not hallucinate.

Do not use Markdown formatting. Do not prefix headings with "#" or any special characters.

Are you ready?
[STARTING NOTE START]
HPI:

Physical Exam:

Laboratory Results:

Imaging Results:

Procedure:

Male Cystoscopy
Risks and benefits of the procedure including infection, bleeding, pain, and urinary retention were
discussed. All questions were answered. Informed consent was obtained. Antibiotic prophylaxis was
given. Sterile technique and intraurethral analgesia were used. The flexible cystoscope was inserted, and
cystourethroscopy performed.
Meatus: Normal size and location
Urethra: No strictures or lesions
External Sphincter: Normal
Verumontanum: Normal
Prostate: ***

given to call the office immediately for blood in the urine, difficulty urinating, urinary retention, painful or
frequent urination, fever, chills, nausea, vomiting or other illness.
[Male Cystoscopy Template End]

Plan:
[STARTING NOTE END]
[REFERENCE NOTE1 START] 

 REFERRING PROVIDER:
Dr.Palmore Cohen

CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Elevated hemoglobin and slightly low platelet count 

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Dear Dr. Palmore Cohen,

I saw Mr. Flores Olovan today in my office for hematology consultation. His history is well known to you but I will take the time to review it for the completeness of my records. 

Mr. Flores Olovan is a pleasant 74 year old gentleman with a history of diabetes mellitus type 2 and hypertension. Recent lab work showed an elevated hemoglobin, unfortunately I do not have those results with me.

CBC today showed: WBC 6.5, hemoglobin 16.8, hematocrit 52.0, MCV 90.9, platelet count 132. His creatinine was 0.62. He has no personal or family history of thrombosis or malignancy. He does not use testosterone injections/gels and does not live at high altitude.

Given the elevated hemoglobin, further evaluation is indicated to rule out polycythemia vera or hemochromatosis.

SOCIAL HISTORY:

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
A 14 point review of system was negative with the exception of what is mentioned in the HPI

OBJECTIVE:
ECOG 0: Fully active, able to carry on all predisease performance without restriction
Physical Examination:
Constitutional Alert, cooperative, oriented. Mood and affect appropriate. Appears close to chronological age. Well nourished. Well developed.
Head Normocephalic; no scars.
Eyes Conjunctivae and sclerae are clear and without icterus. Pupils are reactive and equal.
ENMT Sinuses are nontender. No oral exudates, ulcers, masses, thrush or mucositis. Oropharynx clear. Tongue normal.
Neck Supple without masses or thyromegaly. No jugular venous distension.
Hematologic/Lymphatic No petechiae or purpura. No tender or palpable lymph nodes in the cervical, supraclavicular, axillary or inguinal area.
Respiratory Lungs are clear to auscultation without rhonchi or wheezing.
Cardiovascular Regular rate and rhythm of heart without murmurs, gallops or rubs.
Chest Chest is symmetric without chest wall deformities.
Abdomen Non-tender, non-distended, no masses, ascites or hepatosplenomegaly. Good bowel sounds. No guarding or rebound tenderness. No pulsatile masses.
Back/Spine No kyphosis, scoliosis, compression fractures. Non-tender to palpation.
Musculoskeletal No tenderness or swelling, normal range of motion without obvious weakness.
Extremities No visible deformities, no cyanosis, clubbing or edema. Pulses 4+ and equal bilaterally.
Integumentary No rashes, scars, or lesions suggestive of malignancy.
Neurologic No sensory or motor deficits, normal cerebellar function, normal gait, cranial nerves intact.
Psychiatric Alert and oriented times three. Coherent speech. Verbalizes understanding of our discussions today.

LABORATORY RESULTS:
11-22-2023: CBC: WBC-6.5, Hb-16.8, Hct-52.0, MCV-90.9, Platelet count-132. Creatinine-0.62.

IMAGING RESULTS:

IMPRESSION:
1. Erythrocytosis, rule out polycythemia vera or hemochromatosis
2. Thrombocytosis
3. Diabetes mellitus type 2
4. Chronic kidney disease
5. Vitamin B12 deficiency

DISCUSSION:
Mr. Flores Olovan is a pleasant 74 year old with an elevated hemoglobin. We will evaluate for hemochromatosis and polycythemia vera with testing including HIV, hemochromatosis gene analysis, ferritin, iron studies, erythropoietin level, JAK2 mutation analysis. I will call him the results in a couple weeks. I would like to recheck CBC in 3 and 6 months to ensure the hemoglobin does not continue to rise. Once we have results back, we will make treatment recommendations. He is currently asymptomatic.

This was all discussed with the patient who voiced understanding. All questions were answered, reassurances given, and counseling provided.

Thank you for allowing me to participate in the care of this pleasant gentleman. I will update you on his progress.

PLAN:
- Rule out Polycythemia Vera or Hemochromatosis as the cause of high Hemoglobin through further genetic and iron panel tests.
- Monitor his blood counts in the next 3 and 6 months to ensure no further elevation in hemoglobin.
- Continue to manage his Type 2 diabetes and Chronic kidney disease effectively.
- Will contact him within a couple of weeks with the test results.

Referrals:
None at this time.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software. 

 [REFERENCE NOTE1 END]

mdm_suggested: {"complexity": {"problems": [{"type": "CHRONIC_STABLE", "meta": {"name": "Osteoarthritis of right knee", "details": "Tricompartmental osteoarthritis with moderate to severe changes, currently stable with pain level 0-1/10"}}, {"type": "CHRONIC_STABLE", "meta": {"name": "Osteoarthritis of left knee", "details": "Minimal osteoarthritis with minimal symptoms"}}]}, "risk": {"type": "MODERATE", "meta": {"rationale": "Prescription drug management with corticosteroid injection administered and plan for viscosupplementation therapy"}}, "data": {"items": [{"type": "REVIEW_RESULT", "meta": {"name": "Laboratory studies", "context": "Review of CBC, kidney and liver function tests, uric acid, Vitamin D, B12, glucose, rheumatoid factor from 6/5/25"}}, {"type": "REVIEW_RESULT", "meta": {"name": "X-rays", "context": "Review of bilateral knee and shoulder X-rays from 6/9/25"}}, {"type": "REVIEW_RESULT", "meta": {"name": "Previous MRI", "context": "Review of shoulder MRI from 8/30/2018"}}]}}
history_of_present_illness: Mr. Charles Gibbs is a 74-year-old male presenting for his first rheumatology evaluation. He reports a history of right knee problems for "a few decades" with progressive decline in function. Six years ago, he was nearly scheduled for knee replacement surgery but was advised by his physical therapist that he could potentially delay surgery with appropriate management. Patient reports that his right knee pain is currently mild (2.5/10) at rest with no pain while sitting. Pain increases with certain activities, particularly when "coming down the wrong way" and can reach 4-5/10 at which point he backs off activity. He notes limitations in his ability to bike as he used to, though he maintains an exercise regimen including riding a stationary bike 3 times weekly for 20 minutes. He practices two different schools of Tai Chi and performs strengthening and stretching exercises.Patient also reports bilateral shoulder pain described as "creepy shoulders" for approximately 7 years. He was previously evaluated by an orthopedist in Maryland who reviewed x-rays of his knees and shoulders and concluded he was "a great candidate for surgery in all joints" but he has been managing conservatively.Of note, in 2020, the patient experienced an episode of migratory joint pain that began with tightness in his right groin, then moved to his hip, and subsequently affected both shoulders. The shoulder pain was severe, making it difficult to put on shirts or lie down in bed, described as feeling "like someone was sticking needles in my shoulders." This occurred during early COVID pandemic, and he managed with self-directed physical therapy. By the time he was able to see a physician, symptoms had resolved, and blood work showed no inflammatory markers. This constellation of symptoms has not recurred.Patient had arthroscopic surgery on his left knee "a long time ago" which he states "put me off surgery forever if I can avoid it." He reports an episode approximately 10 years ago (2015) when his left knee locked after sitting cross-legged to meditate, and he was unable to unlock it for about 5 days. Records indicate "a large lateral meniscus tear with a displaced fragment and medial meniscus" at that time, but he declined surgery.Previous imaging from 2020 in Houston reportedly showed osteoarthritis of the right knee. Patient is currently working with a physical therapist at Atlantic Physical Therapy.

plan:
Administered corticosteroid injection to right knee today.
Patient instructed to apply ice to injection site for 5 minutes twice today, then may apply heat as needed.
Will submit prior authorization for viscosupplementation (Orthovisc) for bilateral knees.
Patient may consider hyperbaric oxygen therapy before and after gel injections as discussed.
Laboratory studies from 6/5/25 reviewed with patient showing normal CBC, kidney and liver function tests.
Uric acid level 5.9, Vitamin D 57.4, B12 559, glucose 127 (random), rheumatoid factor negative.
No evidence of inflammatory arthritis on laboratory evaluation.
Patient to continue current exercise regimen including Tai Chi and strengthening exercises.
Follow-up appointment scheduled in 4 weeks to reassess symptoms and discuss viscosupplementation if approved.

reference_summarize_jobs:
[['CHIEF COMPLAINT: 
Management of joint pains/ PsA 

INTERVAL HISTORY:
4/14/25: Patient presents with right knee and leg pain. She reports the right knee cap was very swollen about a month ago and she went to the emergency department due to concern for blood clot, which was ruled out. She has been experiencing pain in both the right upper and lower extremity for several weeks. Patient also notes recurrence of scalp psoriasis. She has been taking Otezla once daily instead of the prescribed twice daily dosing.

MEDICATIONS:
Otezla 30mg (currently taking once daily, should be twice daily)
Cymbalta 60mg for pain

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear. Nodes: No peripheral adenopathy. Chest: Clear bilaterally. Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat.
Abd: Soft, +BS, non tender and non distended, no masses, no organomegaly. Ext: No edema. Skin: Visible scalp psoriasis lesions. Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact. 
Musculoskeletal: Right knee with mild tenderness on palpation, significant narrowing of joint space consistent with osteoarthritis.

ASSESSMENT:
PsA-    low  grade  - stable  on Otezla    Rt thumb pain and  swelling  - good response to    PDN taper- GC inj
B/l knee pain -    OA    related -    s/p    GC inj and  Orthovisc  - with  good response
Erosive osteoarthritis involving bilateral hands based on x-rays.   No improvement with Tylenol, and only partial  response to  prednisone taper.     Good  response to    Otezla,( samples only )    but not  covered  by  insurance. Start MTX.   Tolerating well.
Knee pain secondary to  DJD.   Tried with partial response to p. o. NSAIDs, GC injection, PT.
Plaque psoriasis,    had been  on Ilumya-managed by her dermatologist.   Now  off all meds-   recurrence noted as Otezla dec to QD 
Osteopenia,  low risk FRAX
HTN
Hypothyroidism
High Cholesterol

PLAN:
Administered corticosteroid injection to right knee today.
Patient to apply ice to injection site for 5 minutes twice, then may apply heat as needed.
Increased Otezla to prescribed dose of 30mg twice daily.
Provided Otezla samples for patient to continue therapy.
Will initiate approval process for Skyrizi as potential alternative therapy that may better address skin manifestations.
Laboratory studies reviewed from 1/30/25 showing elevated ESR at 64 (previous 93), CRP WNL, and WBC 29.9 (previous 37).
Patient to return for follow-up bloodwork on 6/2/25 and follow-up visit on 6/9/25.
Patient reports upcoming travel to Puerto Rico on 6/27/25.
Patient reports annual mammogram completed with normal results.
Patient has had recent CT scan, X-ray, and arterial study of legs.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.', 0], ["CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and management of joint and muscle pain

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Mr. Vidal is a 62-year-old male who presents to the rheumatology clinic for evaluation of joint and muscle pain. The patient has a 10-year history of gout, initially diagnosed when crystals were identified in joint fluid. He reports that his current symptoms differ from his typical gout flares. For the past six months, he has been experiencing muscle pain primarily in his left shoulder and left leg. The pain is described as severe and has been progressively worsening. He notes that the pain is particularly bad at night and sometimes makes it difficult for him to walk when he gets out of bed.

The patient has been treated with prednisone 20mg daily for the past two months, which he takes intermittently (typically for about a week until symptoms improve, then stops). When he discontinues prednisone, the pain returns within a few days. He reports previous trials of muscle relaxers and gabapentin without significant relief. He is currently on febuxostat for gout management.  In the past few months he has become compliant with the medication.  His uric acid now is less than 5.

Recent laboratory testing from March 13, 2025 showed a uric acid level of 3.1, which is well-controlled. His CRP was elevated at 9.4, but ESR was normal at 10. Previous laboratory testing from October 2023 showed WBC 7.8, hemoglobin 14.3, hematocrit 42.8, platelets 237, glucose 94, BUN 13, creatinine 0.95, sodium 142, potassium 4.5, chloride 102, CO2 26, calcium 9.6, alkaline phosphatase 79, AST 17, ALT 24, T4 1.2, TSH 0.668, phosphorus 3.4, GGT 61, creatine kinase 62, aldolase 4.5, magnesium 2.2.

The patient also reports a history of Raynaud's phenomenon for many years, which it seems to be treated conservatively. He recently had an elevated PSA of 9 (up from 8 three months ago) and is scheduled for a prostate MRI.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Gout, diagnosed approximately 10 years ago
2. Hypertension
3. Hypercholesterolemia
4. Raynaud's phenomenon
5. Degenerative disc disease (L2-L3)
6. Tinea versicolor (resolved)
7. Sun allergy (per dermatologist)

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:
LASIK eye surgery, date unknown

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Marital Status: Married
Living Arrangements: With Spouse
Tobacco Use:  Former Smoker (quit after approximately 30 years of smoking)
Alcohol Use: Currently uses
Drinks per Day: 1
Illicit Drug use: Negative

OCCUPATION:
Painter

FAMILY HISTORY:
Mother with history of gout

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. 
HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear.  Auricular tophi present
Nodes: No cervical adenopathy. 
Chest: Clear bilaterally. 
Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat.
Ext: No edema. 
Skin: no rash. 
Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact. 
Musculoskeletal: Normal gait. Left shoulder with tenderness to palpation and pain with passive range of motion.  Hawkins sign positive on the left, negative on the right.  Liftoff test negative bilaterally at this point in time. Crepitus noted in right knee. No swelling, erythema, or warmth in any joints. No tophi observed. Full range of motion in all other joints.  Crepitus noted on extension and flexion of the knees bilaterally.  No tenderness on palpation of the MTP joints bilaterally.

ASSESSMENT:
1. Bilateral shoulder pain, left worse than right, with limited range of motion on left side. Pain is currently controlled with prednisone. Differential diagnosis includes rotator cuff pathology, osteoarthritis, or referred pain from cervical spine. X-rays of bilateral shoulders and cervical spine ordered to evaluate further. Patient reports significant pain relief with prednisone but symptoms return quickly upon discontinuation.

2. Right knee pain with crepitus on examination. Likely osteoarthritis. X-rays of bilateral knees ordered for comparison and to assess severity.

3. Gout, well-controlled with current uric acid level of 3.1. Patient has history of crystal-proven gout with previous tophi in ears. Current symptoms are unlikely to be related to active gout given well-controlled uric acid levels. Discussed importance of dietary modifications including avoiding red meat, seafood, alcohol, and high-fructose foods. Recommended increasing intake of dark berries, cherries, low-fat dairy products, and vitamin C-rich foods.

4. Raynaud's phenomenon, untreated. Discussed conservative management including avoiding caffeine, wearing mittens instead of gloves, wearing multiple layers of clothing, and avoiding cold environments. Current amlodipine dose of 2.5mg which she is on for his blood pressure has not shown any improvement in his Raynaud's


PLAN:
Order bilateral shoulder, bilateral knee, bilateral hip, cervical spine, and lumbar spine x-rays to evaluate for osteoarthritis or other structural abnormalities.

Order comprehensive rheumatologic laboratory workup including SCL-70, ESR, CRP, urine protein/creatinine ratio, rheumatoid factor, urine, C3, C4, CCP, RNP, Smith antibodies, double-stranded DNA, ANA, CMP, CBC, cryoglobulins, urinalysis, SSA and SSB.

Taper prednisone as follows: 15mg daily for 5 days, 10mg daily for 5 days, 5mg daily for 6 days, then discontinue. Instructed patient to take prednisone in the morning with food rather than at night.

Recommend discontinuation of caffeine to help manage Raynaud's phenomenon.

Reinforce gout diet: avoid red meat, seafood, alcohol, and processed foods with high fructose corn syrup. Encourage consumption of dark berries, cherries, low-fat dairy, and vitamin C-rich foods.

Return to clinic in 3 weeks to review test results and reassess symptoms after prednisone taper.
", 0], ["CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and management of joint pain

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Dilores A. Ortiz is a 71-year-old female who presents for evaluation of joint pain, particularly in the shoulders, right knee, and left knee. The patient reports longstanding joint pain spanning several years. The patient notes significant difficulty lifting her arms due to shoulder pain. There is a history of prior shoulder imaging done on 09/14/24, which showed calcific tendonitis of the rotator cuff.

The patient notes an inability to walk without the use of topical treatments like Voltaren, citing severe pain especially in the right knee, which also reveals visible swelling. She previously had seen a rheumatologist 3 years ago where she was given an alleged diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis and was placed on Humira. Humira, last taken in June 2022, which notably alleviated symptoms at that time.

Laboratory work conducted in January 2025 showed a cardiac CRP level of 0.7, with trace protein and bacteria present in the urine along with squamous epithelial cells. Systemic and visual exams reveal no significant current conditions such as blurry vision, chest pain, shortness of breath, skin rashes, gastrointestinal, or neurological symptoms aside from cold sensitivity in the fingertips.

The patient's diabetes and hypertension contribute to fluctuating blood sugar and blood pressure levels, limiting the use of certain medications like steroids due to glycemic side effects. She denies any recent tick bites or relevant exposures.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
Diabetes
High cholesterol
Hypertension

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:
Meniscus repair in the left knee (date undisclosed)

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Illicit Drug use: Negative


FAMILY HISTORY:
Father had scoliosis of the spine
No significant arthritis reported in maternal lineage

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below.

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished.
HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear.
Nodes: No peripheral adenopathy.
Chest: Clear bilaterally.
Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat.
Ext: No edema.
Skin: no rash.
Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact.
Musculoskeletal: Swelling noted in the right knee.  Patient has significant Heberden and Bouchard nodule bilaterally in the hands.  No swelling or tenderness noted in the MCP, PIP or DIP joints bilaterally. No signs of ulnar deviation.

ASSESSMENT:
Chronic Joint Pain: The patient presents with chronic joint pain, particularly affecting the shoulders and knees. Possible osteoarthritis suspected based on physical exam findings and shoulder x-ray showing calcific tendonitis.
Osteoarthritis: Suspected given the presentation of symptoms and hand appearance consistent with advanced osteoarthritis. Discussion with patient involved symptomatology distinctions between osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis, focusing on the age of onset and typical progression.
Calcific Tendonitis: Previous imaging confirms calcific changes in the shoulder, suggesting an association with osteoarthritis.

Rheumatoid Arthritis: Clinically less likely due to the current lack of deformities typical of untreated longstanding rheumatoid arthritis but we will obtain further work. Question is if patient has severe erosive causing her symptoms.

PLAN:
Obtain x-rays of hands and knees to assess the extent of osteoarthritic changes Versus erosive osteoarthritis versus inflammatory arthritis.
Refer to an orthopedist for evaluation and drainage of the right knee effusion and subsequent fluid analysis (Cell count, Gram stain, crystal analysis, cultures).
Will order, ANA, Inflammatory hepatitis panel, QuantiFERON gold, hepatitis C antibody, CCP, CBC, CRP, rheumatoid factor, Lyme antibody, ESR, CRP

Discussed the possibility of starting appropriate pharmacologic therapy if any inflammatory arthritis is confirmed.

Plan follow-up in four weeks to review imaging and lab results; adjust management plan depending on findings.

reviewed_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT: Evaluation and management of right knee osteoarthritis and bilateral shoulder pain

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Mr. Charles Gibbs is a 74-year-old male presenting for his first rheumatology evaluation. He reports a history of right knee problems for "a few decades" with progressive decline in function. Six years ago, he was nearly scheduled for knee replacement surgery but was advised by his physical therapist that he could potentially delay surgery with appropriate management. Patient reports that his right knee pain is currently mild (2.5/10) at rest with no pain while sitting. Pain increases with certain activities, particularly when "coming down the wrong way" and can reach 4-5/10 at which point he backs off activity. He notes limitations in his ability to bike as he used to, though he maintains an exercise regimen including riding a stationary bike 3 times weekly for 20 minutes. He practices two different schools of Tai Chi and performs strengthening and stretching exercises.Patient also reports bilateral shoulder pain described as "creepy shoulders" for approximately 7 years. He was previously evaluated by an orthopedist in Maryland who reviewed x-rays of his knees and shoulders and concluded he was "a great candidate for surgery in all joints" but he has been managing conservatively.Of note, in 2020, the patient experienced an episode of migratory joint pain that began with tightness in his right groin, then moved to his hip, and subsequently affected both shoulders. The shoulder pain was severe, making it difficult to put on shirts or lie down in bed, described as feeling "like someone was sticking needles in my shoulders." This occurred during early COVID pandemic, and he managed with self-directed physical therapy. By the time he was able to see a physician, symptoms had resolved, and blood work showed no inflammatory markers. This constellation of symptoms has not recurred.Patient had arthroscopic surgery on his left knee "a long time ago" which he states "put me off surgery forever if I can avoid it." He reports an episode approximately 10 years ago (2015) when his left knee locked after sitting cross-legged to meditate, and he was unable to unlock it for about 5 days. Records indicate "a large lateral meniscus tear with a displaced fragment and medial meniscus" at that time, but he declined surgery.Previous imaging from 2020 in Houston reportedly showed osteoarthritis of the right knee. Patient is currently working with a physical therapist at Atlantic Physical Therapy.

INTERVAL HISTORY:
7/10/2025: Patient returns for follow-up after labs and imaging were ordered at previous visit on 6/5/2025. Patient reports pain level of 0-1/10 in bilateral knees and shoulders. Patient continues to practice Tai Chi and performs regular exercises. Patient reports playing recreational activities including badminton and croquet with grandchildren.

MEDICATIONS:
Inside         Drug         Script Date         Qty         Rfls         Instructions                               coenzyme Q10 10 mg capsule         6/5/2025                   0

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. HEENT:PERRLA,EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear. Nodes: No peripheral adenopathy. Chest: Clear bilaterally. Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat.
Abd: Soft, +BS, non tender and non distended, no masses, no organomegaly. Ext: No edema. Skin: no rash. Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact. Musculoskeletal: Normal gait.

ASSESSMENT:
Osteoarthritis of the right knee - Patient presents with tricompartmental osteoarthritis of the right knee confirmed on X-ray from 6/9/25. Moderate to severe changes noted with small joint effusion present. Patient reports pain level of 0-1/10 currently. Administered corticosteroid injection to right knee today. Discussed gel injections (Orthovisc) as next step in management. Will submit prior authorization for bilateral knee viscosupplementation as left knee shows minimal osteoarthritis with possible small joint effusion on X-ray. Patient educated on post-injection care including ice application and activity modification for remainder of day.

Osteoarthritis of the left knee - Minimal osteoarthritis noted on X-ray from 6/9/25 with possible small joint effusion. Patient reports minimal symptoms. Will include in viscosupplementation request to prevent progression of disease.

Bilateral shoulder pain - Patient reports ongoing mild bilateral shoulder pain. X-rays from 6/9/25 show normal skeletal structures bilaterally. Previous MRI from 8/30/2018 (Maryland) was discussed. Given the 7-year interval since previous imaging, consideration for updated MRI may be warranted if symptoms persist or worsen.

History of migratory joint pain (resolved) - No recurrence of migratory joint symptoms since 2020 episode. Laboratory studies from 6/5/25 show no evidence of inflammatory arthritis with normal inflammatory markers. Rheumatoid factor negative, anti-CCP negative, normal ESR/CRP.

PLAN:
Administered corticosteroid injection to right knee today.
Patient instructed to apply ice to injection site for 5 minutes twice today, then may apply heat as needed.
Will submit prior authorization for viscosupplementation (Orthovisc) for bilateral knees.
Patient may consider hyperbaric oxygen therapy before and after gel injections as discussed.
Laboratory studies from 6/5/25 reviewed with patient showing normal CBC, kidney and liver function tests.
Uric acid level 5.9, Vitamin D 57.4, B12 559, glucose 127 (random), rheumatoid factor negative.
No evidence of inflammatory arthritis on laboratory evaluation.
Patient to continue current exercise regimen including Tai Chi and strengthening exercises.
Follow-up appointment scheduled in 4 weeks to reassess symptoms and discuss viscosupplementation if approved.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.

summarize_job_log.5:response:
Message(id='msg_011GAybQJ1miemoHi4dMYsWk', content=[TextBlock(citations=None, text='CHIEF COMPLAINT: Evaluation and management of right knee osteoarthritis and bilateral shoulder pain

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Mr. Charles Gibbs is a 74-year-old male presenting for his first rheumatology evaluation. He reports a history of right knee problems for "a few decades" with progressive decline in function. Six years ago, he was nearly scheduled for knee replacement surgery but was advised by his physical therapist that he could potentially delay surgery with appropriate management. Patient reports that his right knee pain is currently mild (2.5/10) at rest with no pain while sitting. Pain increases with certain activities, particularly when "coming down the wrong way" and can reach 4-5/10 at which point he backs off activity. He notes limitations in his ability to bike as he used to, though he maintains an exercise regimen including riding a stationary bike 3 times weekly for 20 minutes. He practices two different schools of Tai Chi and performs strengthening and stretching exercises.Patient also reports bilateral shoulder pain described as "creepy shoulders" for approximately 7 years. He was previously evaluated by an orthopedist in Maryland who reviewed x-rays of his knees and shoulders and concluded he was "a great candidate for surgery in all joints" but he has been managing conservatively.Of note, in 2020, the patient experienced an episode of migratory joint pain that began with tightness in his right groin, then moved to his hip, and subsequently affected both shoulders. The shoulder pain was severe, making it difficult to put on shirts or lie down in bed, described as feeling "like someone was sticking needles in my shoulders." This occurred during early COVID pandemic, and he managed with self-directed physical therapy. By the time he was able to see a physician, symptoms had resolved, and blood work showed no inflammatory markers. This constellation of symptoms has not recurred.Patient had arthroscopic surgery on his left knee "a long time ago" which he states "put me off surgery forever if I can avoid it." He reports an episode approximately 10 years ago (2015) when his left knee locked after sitting cross-legged to meditate, and he was unable to unlock it for about 5 days. Records indicate "a large lateral meniscus tear with a displaced fragment and medial meniscus" at that time, but he declined surgery.Previous imaging from 2020 in Houston reportedly showed osteoarthritis of the right knee. Patient is currently working with a physical therapist at Atlantic Physical Therapy.

INTERVAL HISTORY:
7/10/2025: Patient returns for follow-up after labs and imaging were ordered at previous visit on 6/5/2025. Patient reports pain level of 0-1/10 in bilateral knees and shoulders. Patient continues to practice Tai Chi and performs regular exercises. Patient reports playing recreational activities including badminton and croquet with grandchildren.

MEDICATIONS:
Inside         Drug         Script Date         Qty         Rfls         Instructions                               coenzyme Q10 10 mg capsule         6/5/2025                   0

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. HEENT:PERRLA,EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear. Nodes: No peripheral adenopathy. Chest: Clear bilaterally. Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat.
Abd: Soft, +BS, non tender and non distended, no masses, no organomegaly. Ext: No edema. Skin: no rash. Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact. Musculoskeletal: Normal gait.

ASSESSMENT:
Osteoarthritis of the right knee - Patient presents with tricompartmental osteoarthritis of the right knee confirmed on X-ray from 6/9/25. Moderate to severe changes noted with small joint effusion present. Patient reports pain level of 0-1/10 currently. Administered corticosteroid injection to right knee today. Discussed gel injections (Orthovisc) as next step in management. Will submit prior authorization for bilateral knee viscosupplementation as left knee shows minimal osteoarthritis with possible small joint effusion on X-ray. Patient educated on post-injection care including ice application and activity modification for remainder of day.

Osteoarthritis of the left knee - Minimal osteoarthritis noted on X-ray from 6/9/25 with possible small joint effusion. Patient reports minimal symptoms. Will include in viscosupplementation request to prevent progression of disease.

Bilateral shoulder pain - Patient reports ongoing mild bilateral shoulder pain. X-rays from 6/9/25 show normal skeletal structures bilaterally. Previous MRI from 8/30/2018 (Maryland) was discussed. Given the 7-year interval since previous imaging, consideration for updated MRI may be warranted if symptoms persist or worsen.

History of migratory joint pain (resolved) - No recurrence of migratory joint symptoms since 2020 episode. Laboratory studies from 6/5/25 show no evidence of inflammatory arthritis with normal inflammatory markers. Rheumatoid factor negative, anti-CCP negative, normal ESR/CRP.

PLAN:
Administered corticosteroid injection to right knee today.
Patient instructed to apply ice to injection site for 5 minutes twice today, then may apply heat as needed.
Will submit prior authorization for viscosupplementation (Orthovisc) for bilateral knees.
Patient may consider hyperbaric oxygen therapy before and after gel injections as discussed.
Laboratory studies from 6/5/25 reviewed with patient showing normal CBC, kidney and liver function tests.
Uric acid level 5.9, Vitamin D 57.4, B12 559, glucose 127 (random), rheumatoid factor negative.
No evidence of inflammatory arthritis on laboratory evaluation.
Patient to continue current exercise regimen including Tai Chi and strengthening exercises.
Follow-up appointment scheduled in 4 weeks to reassess symptoms and discuss viscosupplementation if approved.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.', type='text')], model='claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219', role='assistant', stop_reason='end_turn', stop_sequence=None, type='message', usage=Usage(cache_creation_input_tokens=0, cache_read_input_tokens=0, input_tokens=11323, output_tokens=1434, service_tier='standard'))

 CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and management of joint and muscle pain

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Mr. Vidal is a 62-year-old male who presents to the rheumatology clinic for evaluation of joint and muscle pain. The patient has a 10-year history of gout, initially diagnosed when crystals were identified in joint fluid. He reports that his current symptoms differ from his typical gout flares. For the past six months, he has been experiencing muscle pain primarily in his left shoulder and left leg. The pain is described as severe and has been progressively worsening. He notes that the pain is particularly bad at night and sometimes makes it difficult for him to walk when he gets out of bed.

The patient has been treated with prednisone 20mg daily for the past two months, which he takes intermittently (typically for about a week until symptoms improve, then stops). When he discontinues prednisone, the pain returns within a few days. He reports previous trials of muscle relaxers and gabapentin without significant relief. He is currently on febuxostat for gout management.  In the past few months he has become compliant with the medication.  His uric acid now is less than 5.

Recent laboratory testing from March 13, 2025 showed a uric acid level of 3.1, which is well-controlled. His CRP was elevated at 9.4, but ESR was normal at 10. Previous laboratory testing from October 2023 showed WBC 7.8, hemoglobin 14.3, hematocrit 42.8, platelets 237, glucose 94, BUN 13, creatinine 0.95, sodium 142, potassium 4.5, chloride 102, CO2 26, calcium 9.6, alkaline phosphatase 79, AST 17, ALT 24, T4 1.2, TSH 0.668, phosphorus 3.4, GGT 61, creatine kinase 62, aldolase 4.5, magnesium 2.2.

The patient also reports a history of Raynaud's phenomenon for many years, which it seems to be treated conservatively. He recently had an elevated PSA of 9 (up from 8 three months ago) and is scheduled for a prostate MRI.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Gout, diagnosed approximately 10 years ago
2. Hypertension
3. Hypercholesterolemia
4. Raynaud's phenomenon
5. Degenerative disc disease (L2-L3)
6. Tinea versicolor (resolved)
7. Sun allergy (per dermatologist)

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:
LASIK eye surgery, date unknown

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Marital Status: Married
Living Arrangements: With Spouse
Tobacco Use:  Former Smoker (quit after approximately 30 years of smoking)
Alcohol Use: Currently uses
Drinks per Day: 1
Illicit Drug use: Negative

OCCUPATION:
Painter

FAMILY HISTORY:
Mother with history of gout

The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. 
HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear.  Auricular tophi present
Nodes: No cervical adenopathy. 
Chest: Clear bilaterally. 
Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat.
Ext: No edema. 
Skin: no rash. 
Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact. 
Musculoskeletal: Normal gait. Left shoulder with tenderness to palpation and pain with passive range of motion.  Hawkins sign positive on the left, negative on the right.  Liftoff test negative bilaterally at this point in time. Crepitus noted in right knee. No swelling, erythema, or warmth in any joints. No tophi observed. Full range of motion in all other joints.  Crepitus noted on extension and flexion of the knees bilaterally.  No tenderness on palpation of the MTP joints bilaterally.

ASSESSMENT:
1. Bilateral shoulder pain, left worse than right, with limited range of motion on left side. Pain is currently controlled with prednisone. Differential diagnosis includes rotator cuff pathology, osteoarthritis, or referred pain from cervical spine. X-rays of bilateral shoulders and cervical spine ordered to evaluate further. Patient reports significant pain relief with prednisone but symptoms return quickly upon discontinuation.

2. Right knee pain with crepitus on examination. Likely osteoarthritis. X-rays of bilateral knees ordered for comparison and to assess severity.

3. Gout, well-controlled with current uric acid level of 3.1. Patient has history of crystal-proven gout with previous tophi in ears. Current symptoms are unlikely to be related to active gout given well-controlled uric acid levels. Discussed importance of dietary modifications including avoiding red meat, seafood, alcohol, and high-fructose foods. Recommended increasing intake of dark berries, cherries, low-fat dairy products, and vitamin C-rich foods.

4. Raynaud's phenomenon, untreated. Discussed conservative management including avoiding caffeine, wearing mittens instead of gloves, wearing multiple layers of clothing, and avoiding cold environments. Current amlodipine dose of 2.5mg which she is on for his blood pressure has not shown any improvement in his Raynaud's


PLAN:
Order bilateral shoulder, bilateral knee, bilateral hip, cervical spine, and lumbar spine x-rays to evaluate for osteoarthritis or other structural abnormalities.

Order comprehensive rheumatologic laboratory workup including SCL-70, ESR, CRP, urine protein/creatinine ratio, rheumatoid factor, urine, C3, C4, CCP, RNP, Smith antibodies, double-stranded DNA, ANA, CMP, CBC, cryoglobulins, urinalysis, SSA and SSB.

Taper prednisone as follows: 15mg daily for 5 days, 10mg daily for 5 days, 5mg daily for 6 days, then discontinue. Instructed patient to take prednisone in the morning with food rather than at night.

Recommend discontinuation of caffeine to help manage Raynaud's phenomenon.

Reinforce gout diet: avoid red meat, seafood, alcohol, and processed foods with high fructose corn syrup. Encourage consumption of dark berries, cherries, low-fat dairy, and vitamin C-rich foods.

Return to clinic in 3 weeks to review test results and reassess symptoms after prednisone taper.

 CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and management of joint pain

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Dilores A. Ortiz is a 71-year-old female who presents for evaluation of joint pain, particularly in the shoulders, right knee, and left knee. The patient reports longstanding joint pain spanning several years. The patient notes significant difficulty lifting her arms due to shoulder pain. There is a history of prior shoulder imaging done on 09/14/24, which showed calcific tendonitis of the rotator cuff.

The patient notes an inability to walk without the use of topical treatments like Voltaren, citing severe pain especially in the right knee, which also reveals visible swelling. She previously had seen a rheumatologist 3 years ago where she was given an alleged diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis and was placed on Humira. Humira, last taken in June 2022, which notably alleviated symptoms at that time.

Laboratory work conducted in January 2025 showed a cardiac CRP level of 0.7, with trace protein and bacteria present in the urine along with squamous epithelial cells. Systemic and visual exams reveal no significant current conditions such as blurry vision, chest pain, shortness of breath, skin rashes, gastrointestinal, or neurological symptoms aside from cold sensitivity in the fingertips.

The patient's diabetes and hypertension contribute to fluctuating blood sugar and blood pressure levels, limiting the use of certain medications like steroids due to glycemic side effects. She denies any recent tick bites or relevant exposures.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
Diabetes
High cholesterol
Hypertension

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:
Meniscus repair in the left knee (date undisclosed)

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Illicit Drug use: Negative

Father had scoliosis of the spine
No significant arthritis reported in maternal lineage

Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished.
HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear.
Nodes: No peripheral adenopathy.
Chest: Clear bilaterally.
Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat.
Ext: No edema.
Skin: no rash.
Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact.
Musculoskeletal: Swelling noted in the right knee.  Patient has significant Heberden and Bouchard nodule bilaterally in the hands.  No swelling or tenderness noted in the MCP, PIP or DIP joints bilaterally. No signs of ulnar deviation.

ASSESSMENT:
Chronic Joint Pain: The patient presents with chronic joint pain, particularly affecting the shoulders and knees. Possible osteoarthritis suspected based on physical exam findings and shoulder x-ray showing calcific tendonitis.
Osteoarthritis: Suspected given the presentation of symptoms and hand appearance consistent with advanced osteoarthritis. Discussion with patient involved symptomatology distinctions between osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis, focusing on the age of onset and typical progression.
Calcific Tendonitis: Previous imaging confirms calcific changes in the shoulder, suggesting an association with osteoarthritis.

Rheumatoid Arthritis: Clinically less likely due to the current lack of deformities typical of untreated longstanding rheumatoid arthritis but we will obtain further work. Question is if patient has severe erosive causing her symptoms.

PLAN:
Obtain x-rays of hands and knees to assess the extent of osteoarthritic changes Versus erosive osteoarthritis versus inflammatory arthritis.
Refer to an orthopedist for evaluation and drainage of the right knee effusion and subsequent fluid analysis (Cell count, Gram stain, crystal analysis, cultures).
Will order, ANA, Inflammatory hepatitis panel, QuantiFERON gold, hepatitis C antibody, CCP, CBC, CRP, rheumatoid factor, Lyme antibody, ESR, CRP

Discussed the possibility of starting appropriate pharmacologic therapy if any inflammatory arthritis is confirmed.

Plan follow-up in four weeks to review imaging and lab results; adjust management plan depending on findings.

history_of_present_illness: Afrodite Paxos presents for follow-up of kidney stones and hematuria. Patient continues to have blood in her urine today. She previously had a negative cystoscopy and imaging tests that confirmed kidney stones. An ultrasound from March 2024 showed no definitive stone but noted possible mild swelling of the right kidney. Patient reports right-sided flank pain that occurs when sitting for prolonged periods, describing it as "jabbing" pain that makes it difficult to catch her breath. She initially thought it might be sciatica and visited a chiropractor. Patient is planning a trip to Greece with her 92-year-old mother who has dementia. Patient reports significant caregiver stress as she cares for her mother from early morning until midnight daily.

reviewed_note:
HPI:
Afrodite Paxos presents for follow-up of kidney stones and hematuria. Patient continues to have blood in her urine today. She previously had a negative cystoscopy and imaging tests that confirmed kidney stones. An ultrasound from March 2024 showed no definitive stone but noted possible mild swelling of the right kidney. Patient reports right-sided flank pain that occurs when sitting for prolonged periods, describing it as "jabbing" pain that makes it difficult to catch her breath. She initially thought it might be sciatica and visited a chiropractor. Patient is planning a trip to Greece with her 92-year-old mother who has dementia. Patient reports significant caregiver stress as she cares for her mother from early morning until midnight daily.

Physical Exam:
Patient points to right flank area when describing pain. Pain appears to be positional and located higher than typical kidney pain.

Laboratory Results:
Urinalysis shows persistent hematuria.

Imaging Results:
Ultrasound from March 2024 showed no definitive stone but possible mild swelling of the right kidney.

Procedure:

Plan:
1. Nephrolithiasis/Hematuria - Chronic. Patient continues to have microscopic hematuria. Will order renal ultrasound to evaluate for kidney stones and to assess previously noted mild right kidney swelling. Will also order urine cytology to rule out malignancy. Pain described appears to be musculoskeletal rather than renal in origin based on location and positional nature. Will coordinate care with Dr. Forward and send all results. Follow up after ultrasound results; may consider CT scan if ultrasound shows persistent kidney swelling.

 [STARTING NOTE START]
History of Present Illness
Ms. Olivia Sakha presented with concerns about side pain that migrated into her back and severe menstrual cramps. She initially reported right-sided pain, which has extended to the left side, presenting as constant daily bad cramping. This occurred following her period, which she started on two separate occasions this month. The pain is typically significant before the bleeding starts; however, this time the pain has been persistent. Ms. Sakha has been on the birth control pill Nikki since last April, with a loose history of regular menstrual cycles. The cramps have worsened since November last year, She's reported heavy but normal periods before starting birth control. She missed two days of her pill recently while on a trip which she believes could be the cause of her current issues.

Physical Exam
The patient reported her pain to be primarily on her right side but has also pointed to the left side. She expressed intense pain on palpation in the abdominal region up into the back. No evident distress or abnormalities found during the physical exam.

Assessment/Plan
- Ms. Sakha's symptoms indicate possible hormonal imbalance due to missed birth control pills, possibly causing early withdrawal bleeding. I advised her to continue taking her pills regularly.
- The severity of the cramps is a concern. Suggested an ultrasound to rule out ovarian cysts due to an increase in her menstrual cramping in recent months.
- Advised patient to see a primary care physician for a potential kidney ultrasound considering her history of kidney stones and her location of pain.
- The plan includes an in-office ultrasound to assess the patient's ovaries and uterus for possible causes of her symptoms. It was discussed that her symptoms may be due to fluctuations in hormones caused by missed doses of her birth control 

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.
[STARTING NOTE END] 

 [REFERENCE NOTE1 END]
