[['CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and management of positive ANA and scleritis

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Ms. Purvi Nagar is a 51-year-old female who presents to the rheumatology clinic for evaluation of a positive ANA of 1:80. The patient was referred by her ophthalmologist, Dr. Michael Trottini, who diagnosed her allegedly with scleritis. The patient reports that approximately three weeks ago, she developed severe throbbing eye pain with redness and swelling in her right eye, which prompted an emergency room visit. She was subsequently evaluated by Dr. Trottini who prescribed eye drops that she is currently using 2-3 times daily with good control of her symptoms. The optometrist was concerned about "body inflammation" as per patient based on abnormal blood work and referred her to rheumatology.

Laboratory studies from 3/24/25 showed: HLA-B27 negative, negative lyme, ESR 55, CRP 11.4, rheumatoid factor <10 (negative), ANCA panel with myeloperoxidase antibody negative, proteinase 3 antibody negative, HSV IgG negative, QuantiFERON Gold positive, ACE level 27 (negative), and ANA 1:80. Of note, the patient reports having a negative TB test in February 2025 (one month prior to the positive result), which she completes annually as her child is special needs.

The patient denies any joint pain except for mild left knee pain that has been present for a couple of years, which was previously evaluated by an orthopedist who diagnosed early arthritis, likely osteoarthritis. She denies fevers, night sweats, weight loss, fatigue, oral or nasal ulcers, rashes, or significant hair loss. She reports tailbone pain that worsens with prolonged sitting (>2-3 hours), which began after returning from a trip to India in January 2024.  She denies having any history of low back pain.  Denies any significant morning stiffness.  Denies pain waking her up in the middle of the night. 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Anemia
2. Constipation
3. Kidney stones
4. Menopause
5. Tennis elbow

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:
1. Cholecystectomy in 2019 for gallstones
2. Two C-sections

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Marital Status: Married
Living Arrangements: With Spouse
Tobacco Use:  Never Smoker
Alcohol Use: Never
Drinks per Day: 0
Illicit Drug use: Negative

OCCUPATION:
Previously worked as a recruiter from home; laid off 6 months ago; currently not working

FAMILY HISTORY:
Family history of kidney stones (father, grandfather, mother)
No family history of rheumatologic autoimmune diseases that she is aware of 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. 
HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear. 
Nodes: No cervical adenopathy. 
Chest: Clear bilaterally. 
Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat.
Ext: No edema. 
Skin: no rash. 
Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact. 
Musculoskeletal: Normal gait. Hyperextension noted in both elbows. Mild tenderness at medial epicondylitis. No synovitis or swelling noted in any joints in both the upper and lower extremities. Full range of motion in all joints. Mild crepitus in left knee.  No swelling in the knees.  No tenderness on palpation of the MTP joints bilaterally no tenderness on palpation of the Achilles tendon insertion site bilaterally.

ASSESSMENT:
1. Scleritis - Patient has a history of scleritis diagnosed by ophthalmologist Dr. Trottini. Currently symptoms are controlled with prescribed eye drops. No evidence of underlying rheumatologic condition based on physical exam and laboratory studies. Inflammatory markers (ESR 55, CRP 11.4) were elevated, which may be related to the active scleritis at the time of testing. Will repeat inflammatory markers to see if they normalize with resolution of scleritis.

2. Positive ANA 1:80 - Low-titer ANA that is considered clinically insignificant in the absence of symptoms or signs of connective tissue disease. No evidence of lupus, Sjögren's syndrome, or other autoimmune conditions on exam. Will repeat ANA and check additional autoantibodies to further evaluate.

3. Positive QuantiFERON Gold test - Concerning for latent TB, especially given negative test one month prior. Will repeat test to confirm and obtain chest x-ray. If confirmed positive, will refer to infectious disease for further management.

4. Tailbone pain - Likely coccydynia. Will obtain x-rays of lumbar spine, sacrum, and coccyx to evaluate for degenerative changes or other abnormalities.

5. Left knee pain - Likely early osteoarthritis as previously diagnosed by orthopedist. No evidence of inflammatory arthritis on exam.

PLAN:
Will repeat laboratory studies including ANA, inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP), and QuantiFERON Gold test.
Will order chest x-ray to evaluate for evidence of TB.
Will order x-rays of lumbar spine, sacrum, and coccyx to evaluate tailbone pain.
Patient to bring ophthalmology records at next visit.
If QuantiFERON Gold test remains positive, will refer to infectious disease.

Follow-up in 2 weeks to review test results.
', 0], ["RHEUMATOLOGY VISIT NOTE

Date: 06/11/25
Patient: Forster, Katherine
Provider: Dr. Anis
Visit Type: New Patient

CHIEF COMPLAINT: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) with pulmonary hypertension

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Ms. Forster is a 73-year-old female with a complex history of SLE/Rheumatoid arthritis/Sjogren's syndrome?? and Graves' disease. She was sent to the hospital in May 2025 for hypotension. At Jersey City Medical Center, she underwent extensive evaluation and was found to have severe pulmonary hypertension confirmed by right cardiac catheterization. She was also incidentally diagnosed with liver cirrhosis, which she was previously unaware of. She was also found to be leukopenic and thrombocytopenic. She was started on prednisone taper starting with 40 mg for 10 then slow taper. She was also evaluated by rheumatology and serology was concerning for SLE and she was started on plaquenil 200 BID. Due to significant dryness symptoms, she was also started on pilocarpine. She was discharged and instructed to follow up with cardiology, pulmonology, GI, rheumatology and hematology. 

The patient has a history of lupus dating back to the 1980s and was followed by a rheumatologist in Jersey City who is now retired. Her initial presentation included joint pain, primarily in the fingers with swelling. She was initially diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis and treated with gold shots and leflunomide. She was offered Plaquenil but declined due to concerns about side effects. She was also offered Rinvoq but did not try it. She has never been on biologics and was primarily managed with prednisone courses. No history of interna organ involvement before recent hospitalization. She had bilateral knee replacement for degenerative changes.  She also reports significant sicca symptoms for long time and previous diagnosis of sjogren syndrome. 

Prior to her recent hospitalization, she had a skin biopsy of her rash which confirmed discoid lupus or subcutaneous lupus which responded to topical steroid 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (diagnosed 1980s)
2. Rheumatoid Arthritis
3. Sjogren's Syndrome
4. Graves' Disease
5. Severe Pulmonary Hypertension (diagnosed May 2025)
6. Liver Cirrhosis (diagnosed May 2025)
7. Leukopenia
8. Thrombocytopenia

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:
None documented

MEDICATIONS:
1. Prednisone (taper)
2. Hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil)
3. Pilocarpine

ALLERGIES:
None documented

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Not documented

FAMILY HISTORY:
Not documented

OCCUPATION:
Not documented

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
Constitutional: No fever, chills, or weight loss
HEENT: Dry eyes, dry mouth
Cardiovascular: No chest pain, palpitations
Respiratory: Shortness of breath
Gastrointestinal: No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea
Genitourinary: No dysuria or hematuria
Musculoskeletal: Joint pain in fingers historically, no current synovitis
Skin: Rash on upper chest and back
Neurological: No headaches, seizures, or focal deficits
Psychiatric: No depression or anxiety
Endocrine: History of Graves' disease
Hematologic: Easy bruising, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
General: Well-appearing female in no acute distress
Vital Signs: Within normal limits
HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic
Neck: Supple, no lymphadenopathy
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended
Musculoskeletal: No signs of synovitis on exam
Skin: Bruising on upper extremities, periungual erythema in lower extremities, netlike livedo reticularis-type skin rashes over upper chest and upper back
Neurological: Alert and oriented, no focal deficits

LABORATORY FINDINGS:
- Positive ANA
- Low complements
- Slightly elevated SSA antibodies
- Leukopenia
- Thrombocytopenia
- Slightly elevated liver enzymes

ASSESSMENT:
1. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)  
-Patient fulfills criteria for lupus with positive ANA, low complements, slightly elevated SSA antibodies, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and skin rash confirmed as cutaneous lupus by biopsy. 
-Currently managed with prednisone and Plaquenil. 
-No evidence of CNS, nephrology involvement. No evidence of ILD. No signs of joint involvement. 
-Will monitor response to current therapy and consider additional immunosuppression if other organ involvement is identified.
-Should continue with plaquenil 200 mg BID
-For lupus related leukopenia, patient was treated with neupogen 
-For lupus related thrombocytopenia, patient was treated with steroids. Other options if no response include IVIG or RTX 
-For liver cirrhosis, will need to evaluate for lupus related hepatitis and autoimmune hepatitis. Patient is being evaluated by GI. Options will include Azathioprine.  

2. Severe Pulmonary Hypertension - Recently diagnosed by right cardiac catheterization. Patient is following with pulmonology for management. CT scan of chest does not show signs of interstitial lung disease.

3. Liver Cirrhosis - Recently diagnosed, currently being evaluated by gastroenterology for possible autoimmune liver disease. Liver enzymes are slightly elevated.

4. Sjogren's Syndrome - Significant dryness symptoms, currently managed with pilocarpine.

5. History of Rheumatoid Arthritis - Previously treated with gold shots and leflunomide. No current synovitis on examination.

6. Graves' Disease - No acute issues noted.

PLAN:
1. Continue prednisone taper as prescribed.
2. Continue Plaquenil two pills daily.
3. Continue pilocarpine for Sjogren's symptoms.
4. Obtain laboratory studies today to assess disease activity and medication response.
5. Await final liver evaluation from gastroenterology.
6. Assess for kidney involvement with urinalysis and renal function tests.
7. Follow up in one week to review laboratory results and adjust treatment plan as needed.
8. Consider additional immunosuppressive therapy if evidence of progressive organ involvement is found.
9. Continue coordination of care with pulmonology for management of pulmonary hypertension.
10. Continue to monitor blood cell count and follow up with hematology. 
", 0], ['CHIEF COMPLAINT: Evaluation and management of joint pain

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Ms. Hierro is a 49-year-old female who presents to the clinic for evaluation of joint pain. She reports experiencing pain throughout her entire body, particularly in large joints including the neck, shoulders, back, and knees. She also complains of finger swelling stating, "I cannot close them or open fast. I have to do some exercises so that they loose again." The swelling comes and goes. She notes that her joint pain worsens with changes in temperature, particularly when it rains. She experiences morning stiffness. The patient reports these symptoms have been ongoing for years.The patient also reports poor sleep, sleeping only about 4 hours per night with frequent interruptions. She works 10 hours per day. She has tried natural sleep aids prescribed by previous doctors without relief. She denies being evaluated by a sleep specialist.Additionally, she reports color changes in her hands, stating they turn "a really strong violet color" and that she has been losing sensitivity in her fingers with weather changes. She describes the color change starting with a yellowish-white color that then changes rapidly, but states that this happen with hot or cold weather. She experiences numbness in all ten fingers that occurs suddenly without apparent reason.The patient reports she was diagnosed with arthritis in Puerto Rico approximately 9-10 years ago. She has been prescribed prednisone, meloxicam, and Celebrex in the past. She states she has been on prednisone intermittently for about 9-10 years, with her last dose taken 5-6 months ago. She reports, "they've been changing also my medicines along the years, but I always go back to that medicine because it seems that my body is used to it."She reports a previous diagnosis of lupus but is not currently on any treatment for it. She has recently experienced irregular menstruation. Patient states that when she was young she was very flexible.  She was able to touch her thumb to the back of her forearms bilaterally she was able to touch the floor flat with her hands.  She was able to do splits easily.  Denied any shoulder dislocation.  She states she was able to move her knee particularly her left one out of place. Laboratory studies from June 2023 showed: WBC 5.1, hemoglobin 11.1, hematocrit 33.5, platelet count 216, glucose 84, BUN 13, creatinine 0.73, sodium 139, potassium 4.8, chloride 103, carbon dioxide 22, calcium 9.1, alkaline phosphatase 34, AST 37, ALT 22. Urinalysis did not show any RBCs or protein. Thyroid panel showed TSH 1.520, free T4 2.3 (within normal limits). Rheumatoid factor was less than 10. Vitamin D was 34.2. ESR was 26. ANA screen was positive.

INTERVAL HISTORY:
5/2/25: Patient returns for follow-up with recent laboratory and imaging results. Recent autoimmune panel shows negative anti-SCL 70 antibody, beta-2 glycoprotein IgA of 50, beta-2 glycoprotein IgG and IgM less than 9, albumin creatinine ratio of 8 (WNL), smooth muscle antibody of 6 (WNL), mitochondrial antibody less than 20, positive Sjogren SSA antibody (>8), negative SSB antibody, positive Smith antibody (>8), dsDNA of 2 (WNL), CCP antibody of 10, positive ANA at 1:1280 with speckled pattern, positive RNP antibody (>8), SCL70 less than 0.2, positive antichromatin antibody (>8), antiribosomal P antibody of 0.2, negative JO-1, negative anticentromere antibody, negative cold agglutinins, + thyroglobulin antibody of 2.1, and antithyroperoxidase antibody of 114. Urinalysis showed specific gravity of 1.025, 1+ protein, negative WBCs and RBCs.

MEDICATIONS:
Inside         Drug         Script Date         Qty         Rfls         Instructions                               celecoxib 200 mg capsule         4/18/2025                   0                                         clindamycin HCl 300 mg capsule         4/18/2025                   0                                         meloxicam 15 mg tablet         4/18/2025                   0                                         methylprednisolone 4 mg tablet         4/18/2025                   0                                         prednisone 5 mg tablet         4/18/2025                   0

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. 
HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic, extraocular movements intact, no oral ulcers noted. 
Chest: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. 
Heart: Normal S1, S2, regular rate and rhythm. 
Extremities: No pitting edema noted in upper or lower extremities. 
Skin: No skin rash noted. 
Musculoskeletal: No swelling noted in MCP, PIP, or DIP joints in left hand. Right hand fifth PIP joint is slightly tender and subjectively appears somewhat swollen. Tenderness noted throughout whole body with 16 out of 18 fibromyalgia trigger points positive.

ASSESSMENT:
1. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (+ ANA, +RNP, +Smith, +SSA) - Patient has positive ANA (1:1280 with speckled pattern), positive RNP antibody, positive Smith antibody (highly specific for lupus), positive antichromatin antibody, and positive SSA antibody. These findings strongly suggest an underlying inflammatory autoimmune connective tissue disease. Physical examination reveals slight soft tissue swelling in right fifth PIP joint. Will initiate hydroxychloroquine 5 mg/kg. Will also prescribe prednisone 20 mg with taper as a bridge while hydroxychloroquine takes effect.

2. Fibromyalgia - Patient's chronic pain is most consistent with fibromyalgia likely related to hypermobility based on her history. Patient reports history of flexibility in youth, poor sleep, and diffuse pain. Physical exam reveals tenderness at 16 of 18 trigger points. Will first address underlying autoimmune condition with hydroxychloroquine and may consider aqua therapy in the future. Recommended patient discuss fibromyalgia symptoms with her new primary care physician.

3. Raynaud's phenomenon - Patient reports color changes in her hands and fingers with associated numbness. Currently stable. Recommended conservative management including wearing mittens instead of gloves, multiple loose layers of clothing, and being consciously aware of environment. May consider calcium channel blocker in the future if symptoms worsen.

4. Hypermobility - Patient demonstrates hyperextension of elbows and reports history of flexibility. This likely contributes to her chronic pain symptoms.

5. Possible osteoarthritis - Based on history of joint pain that worsens with weather changes and previous diagnosis in Puerto Rico. Imaging shows chronic deformity of fifth DIP and PIP joint in right hand with soft tissue prominence of distal fifth finger. C-spine x-ray shows loss and flattening of normal cervical lordotic curvature, indicating possible paraspinal muscle spasms or strain.

PLAN:
Will start hydroxychloroquine 5 mg/kg - patient to take 200 mg Monday through Saturday and 400 mg on Sunday.
Recommend taking hydroxychloroquine with food in the evening.
Will prescribe prednisone 20 mg with taper as a bridge with concomitant use of hydroxychloroquine.
Patient has appointment with primary care doctor to establish care.


Patient to return to clinic in 8 weeks.

reviewed_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and management of joint pain and fatigue with concern for possible lupus

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Mr. Anthony Moya is a 33-year-old male who presents to rheumatology clinic for evaluation of multiple joint pains, fatigue, and concern for possible lupus. Patient reports his mother has lupus. His symptoms include fatigue, difficulty sleeping, dry mouth, chest pain, constipation, bloating, headaches, memory loss, pain in multiple joints, anxiety, and depression. These symptoms have been present for approximately 4-5 years.

Patient was previously seen in the ER in October 2023 for left arm and leg weakness and numbness. At that time, he had a normal EKG, negative CT head, and negative CT angiogram for large vessel occlusion. An echocardiogram showed no pericardial effusion, normal left ventricular size with ejection fraction of 55-60%, no mitral regurgitation, normal atrial size, and normal tricuspid valve structure. MRI of the cervical spine showed no evidence of cervical spinal cord parenchymal lesions or compression, with a suspected hemangioma noted. Brain MRI was negative according to the radiologist.

Laboratory studies from January 2023 showed negative urinalysis, WBC 7.5, hemoglobin 14.4, hematocrit 44.2, platelet count 216, glucose 94, BUN 17, creatinine 0.91, sodium 141, potassium 4.3, chloride 102, carbon dioxide 25, alkaline phosphatase 66, AST 18, ALT 18.

Patient reports joint pain primarily in his hands, particularly in the PIP joints. He notes that cold provides relief to his joint pain. He experiences chest pain that was previously diagnosed as costochondritis at JFK Hospital. He reports significant shortness of breath with exertion, specifically when playing sports for more than 5 minutes. He denies shortness of breath at rest. Patient also reports significant memory issues/brain fog, requiring him to write everything down to remember tasks and appointments. He reports poor sleep with frequent interruptions, sleeping approximately 6 hours per night. He has not been evaluated by a sleep specialist.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Acid reflux
2. Scoliosis
3. Costochondritis

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:
None reported

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Marital Status: Single
Living Arrangements: With Family
Tobacco Use: Never Smoker
Alcohol Use: Never
Drinks per Day: 0
Illicit Drug use: Negative

OCCUPATION:
Works 10 hours per day, specific occupation not stated

FAMILY HISTORY:
Mother has lupus
Father has sciatica
Grandfather had leg amputation, possibly due to diabetes

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear, no oral ulcers. Nodes: No peripheral adenopathy. Chest: Clear bilaterally. Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat.
Abd: Soft, +BS, non tender and non distended, no masses, no organomegaly. Ext: No edema. Skin: No rash. Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact. Musculoskeletal: Normal gait. No swelling noted in joints in both upper and lower extremities. Faber test negative bilaterally. Tenderness on palpation of trochanteric bursa region bilaterally. Mild crepitus noted on extension and flexion of the knees. No tenderness on palpation of the MTP joints bilaterally. Skin: No rashes noted on extremities or torso. Patient has nails that appear to be chewed on bilaterally. Slight discoloration of the first big toenail bilaterally with some chipping.

ASSESSMENT:
1. Chronic fatigue and joint pain - Clinically, I do not see any signs of underlying rheumatological inflammatory connective tissue disease or arthropathy. The patient does not have any rash, no photosensitivity rash, no oral ulcers, and no significant synovitis in the hands, feet, or any joints. The patient complains of fatigue, anxiety, and poor sleep, which raises concern for chronic fatigue syndrome/chronic pain syndrome. This is a diagnosis of exclusion, and comprehensive blood work will be ordered to rule out other possible etiologies.

2. Acid reflux - Patient reports significant acid reflux with metallic taste in the morning and regurgitation. Previous trial of Pepcid resulted in allergic reaction with itching. Will refer to gastroenterology for further evaluation and management.

3. Poor sleep - Patient reports interrupted sleep of approximately 6 hours per night with frequent awakenings. This may be contributing to his fatigue, joint pain, and cognitive issues. Will refer to sleep medicine for evaluation.

4. Trochanteric bursitis - Patient has tenderness over bilateral trochanteric bursa regions. This may be related to his scoliosis and prolonged sitting for work.

PLAN:
Will order comprehensive laboratory studies including ANA, SSA, SSB, CBC, CMP, ESR, CRP, urinalysis, urine protein/creatinine ratio, RF, C3, C4, CCP, RNP, Smith antibody, double-stranded DNA, hepatitis B core antibody, hepatitis B surface antibody, hepatitis B surface antigen, hepatitis C antibody, and QuantiFERON Gold.

Referral to gastroenterology for evaluation of acid reflux.
Referral to sleep medicine for evaluation of sleep disturbance.
Referral to primary care physician (Dr. Caracetas) for establishment of care.
Patient to return to clinic in two weeks to review laboratory results.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.

Message(id='msg_01TrokK75xPQW7fqDZ13tDkL', content=[TextBlock(citations=None, text='CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and management of joint pain and fatigue with concern for possible lupus

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Mr. Anthony Moya is a 33-year-old male who presents to rheumatology clinic for evaluation of multiple joint pains, fatigue, and concern for possible lupus. Patient reports his mother has lupus. His symptoms include fatigue, difficulty sleeping, dry mouth, chest pain, constipation, bloating, headaches, memory loss, pain in multiple joints, anxiety, and depression. These symptoms have been present for approximately 4-5 years.

Patient was previously seen in the ER in October 2023 for left arm and leg weakness and numbness. At that time, he had a normal EKG, negative CT head, and negative CT angiogram for large vessel occlusion. An echocardiogram showed no pericardial effusion, normal left ventricular size with ejection fraction of 55-60%, no mitral regurgitation, normal atrial size, and normal tricuspid valve structure. MRI of the cervical spine showed no evidence of cervical spinal cord parenchymal lesions or compression, with a suspected hemangioma noted. Brain MRI was negative according to the radiologist.

Laboratory studies from January 2023 showed negative urinalysis, WBC 7.5, hemoglobin 14.4, hematocrit 44.2, platelet count 216, glucose 94, BUN 17, creatinine 0.91, sodium 141, potassium 4.3, chloride 102, carbon dioxide 25, alkaline phosphatase 66, AST 18, ALT 18.

Patient reports joint pain primarily in his hands, particularly in the PIP joints. He notes that cold provides relief to his joint pain. He experiences chest pain that was previously diagnosed as costochondritis at JFK Hospital. He reports significant shortness of breath with exertion, specifically when playing sports for more than 5 minutes. He denies shortness of breath at rest. Patient also reports significant memory issues/brain fog, requiring him to write everything down to remember tasks and appointments. He reports poor sleep with frequent interruptions, sleeping approximately 6 hours per night. He has not been evaluated by a sleep specialist.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Acid reflux
2. Scoliosis
3. Costochondritis

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:
None reported

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Marital Status: Single
Living Arrangements: With Family
Tobacco Use: Never Smoker
Alcohol Use: Never
Drinks per Day: 0
Illicit Drug use: Negative

OCCUPATION:
Works 10 hours per day, specific occupation not stated

FAMILY HISTORY:
Mother has lupus
Father has sciatica
Grandfather had leg amputation, possibly due to diabetes

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear, no oral ulcers. Nodes: No peripheral adenopathy. Chest: Clear bilaterally. Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat.
Abd: Soft, +BS, non tender and non distended, no masses, no organomegaly. Ext: No edema. Skin: No rash. Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact. Musculoskeletal: Normal gait. No swelling noted in joints in both upper and lower extremities. Faber test negative bilaterally. Tenderness on palpation of trochanteric bursa region bilaterally. Mild crepitus noted on extension and flexion of the knees. No tenderness on palpation of the MTP joints bilaterally. Skin: No rashes noted on extremities or torso. Patient has nails that appear to be chewed on bilaterally. Slight discoloration of the first big toenail bilaterally with some chipping.

ASSESSMENT:
1. Chronic fatigue and joint pain - Clinically, I do not see any signs of underlying rheumatological inflammatory connective tissue disease or arthropathy. The patient does not have any rash, no photosensitivity rash, no oral ulcers, and no significant synovitis in the hands, feet, or any joints. The patient complains of fatigue, anxiety, and poor sleep, which raises concern for chronic fatigue syndrome/chronic pain syndrome. This is a diagnosis of exclusion, and comprehensive blood work will be ordered to rule out other possible etiologies.

2. Acid reflux - Patient reports significant acid reflux with metallic taste in the morning and regurgitation. Previous trial of Pepcid resulted in allergic reaction with itching. Will refer to gastroenterology for further evaluation and management.

3. Poor sleep - Patient reports interrupted sleep of approximately 6 hours per night with frequent awakenings. This may be contributing to his fatigue, joint pain, and cognitive issues. Will refer to sleep medicine for evaluation.

4. Trochanteric bursitis - Patient has tenderness over bilateral trochanteric bursa regions. This may be related to his scoliosis and prolonged sitting for work.

PLAN:
Will order comprehensive laboratory studies including ANA, SSA, SSB, CBC, CMP, ESR, CRP, urinalysis, urine protein/creatinine ratio, RF, C3, C4, CCP, RNP, Smith antibody, double-stranded DNA, hepatitis B core antibody, hepatitis B surface antibody, hepatitis B surface antigen, hepatitis C antibody, and QuantiFERON Gold.

Referral to gastroenterology for evaluation of acid reflux.
Referral to sleep medicine for evaluation of sleep disturbance.
Referral to primary care physician (Dr. Caracetas) for establishment of care.
Patient to return to clinic in two weeks to review laboratory results.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.', type='text')], model='claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219', role='assistant', stop_reason='end_turn', stop_sequence=None, type='message', usage=Usage(cache_creation_input_tokens=0, cache_read_input_tokens=0, input_tokens=17034, output_tokens=1434, service_tier='standard'))

[REFERENCE NOTE1 START] 

 CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and management of positive ANA and scleritis

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Ms. Purvi Nagar is a 51-year-old female who presents to the rheumatology clinic for evaluation of a positive ANA of 1:80. The patient was referred by her ophthalmologist, Dr. Michael Trottini, who diagnosed her allegedly with scleritis. The patient reports that approximately three weeks ago, she developed severe throbbing eye pain with redness and swelling in her right eye, which prompted an emergency room visit. She was subsequently evaluated by Dr. Trottini who prescribed eye drops that she is currently using 2-3 times daily with good control of her symptoms. The optometrist was concerned about "body inflammation" as per patient based on abnormal blood work and referred her to rheumatology.

Laboratory studies from 3/24/25 showed: HLA-B27 negative, negative lyme, ESR 55, CRP 11.4, rheumatoid factor <10 (negative), ANCA panel with myeloperoxidase antibody negative, proteinase 3 antibody negative, HSV IgG negative, QuantiFERON Gold positive, ACE level 27 (negative), and ANA 1:80. Of note, the patient reports having a negative TB test in February 2025 (one month prior to the positive result), which she completes annually as her child is special needs.

The patient denies any joint pain except for mild left knee pain that has been present for a couple of years, which was previously evaluated by an orthopedist who diagnosed early arthritis, likely osteoarthritis. She denies fevers, night sweats, weight loss, fatigue, oral or nasal ulcers, rashes, or significant hair loss. She reports tailbone pain that worsens with prolonged sitting (>2-3 hours), which began after returning from a trip to India in January 2024.  She denies having any history of low back pain.  Denies any significant morning stiffness.  Denies pain waking her up in the middle of the night. 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Anemia
2. Constipation
3. Kidney stones
4. Menopause
5. Tennis elbow

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:
1. Cholecystectomy in 2019 for gallstones
2. Two C-sections

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Marital Status: Married
Living Arrangements: With Spouse
Tobacco Use:  Never Smoker
Alcohol Use: Never
Drinks per Day: 0
Illicit Drug use: Negative

OCCUPATION:
Previously worked as a recruiter from home; laid off 6 months ago; currently not working

FAMILY HISTORY:
Family history of kidney stones (father, grandfather, mother)
No family history of rheumatologic autoimmune diseases that she is aware of 

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. 
HEENT: PERRLA, EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear. 
Nodes: No cervical adenopathy. 
Chest: Clear bilaterally. 
Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat.
Ext: No edema. 
Skin: no rash. 
Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact. 
Musculoskeletal: Normal gait. Hyperextension noted in both elbows. Mild tenderness at medial epicondylitis. No synovitis or swelling noted in any joints in both the upper and lower extremities. Full range of motion in all joints. Mild crepitus in left knee.  No swelling in the knees.  No tenderness on palpation of the MTP joints bilaterally no tenderness on palpation of the Achilles tendon insertion site bilaterally.

ASSESSMENT:
1. Scleritis - Patient has a history of scleritis diagnosed by ophthalmologist Dr. Trottini. Currently symptoms are controlled with prescribed eye drops. No evidence of underlying rheumatologic condition based on physical exam and laboratory studies. Inflammatory markers (ESR 55, CRP 11.4) were elevated, which may be related to the active scleritis at the time of testing. Will repeat inflammatory markers to see if they normalize with resolution of scleritis.

2. Positive ANA 1:80 - Low-titer ANA that is considered clinically insignificant in the absence of symptoms or signs of connective tissue disease. No evidence of lupus, Sjögren's syndrome, or other autoimmune conditions on exam. Will repeat ANA and check additional autoantibodies to further evaluate.

3. Positive QuantiFERON Gold test - Concerning for latent TB, especially given negative test one month prior. Will repeat test to confirm and obtain chest x-ray. If confirmed positive, will refer to infectious disease for further management.

4. Tailbone pain - Likely coccydynia. Will obtain x-rays of lumbar spine, sacrum, and coccyx to evaluate for degenerative changes or other abnormalities.

5. Left knee pain - Likely early osteoarthritis as previously diagnosed by orthopedist. No evidence of inflammatory arthritis on exam.

PLAN:
Will repeat laboratory studies including ANA, inflammatory markers (ESR, CRP), and QuantiFERON Gold test.
Will order chest x-ray to evaluate for evidence of TB.
Will order x-rays of lumbar spine, sacrum, and coccyx to evaluate tailbone pain.
Patient to bring ophthalmology records at next visit.
If QuantiFERON Gold test remains positive, will refer to infectious disease.

Follow-up in 2 weeks to review test results.
 

 [REFERENCE NOTE1 END]

[REFERENCE NOTE2 START] 

 RHEUMATOLOGY VISIT NOTE

Date: 06/11/25
Patient: Forster, Katherine
Provider: Dr. Anis
Visit Type: New Patient

CHIEF COMPLAINT: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) with pulmonary hypertension

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Ms. Forster is a 73-year-old female with a complex history of SLE/Rheumatoid arthritis/Sjogren's syndrome?? and Graves' disease. She was sent to the hospital in May 2025 for hypotension. At Jersey City Medical Center, she underwent extensive evaluation and was found to have severe pulmonary hypertension confirmed by right cardiac catheterization. She was also incidentally diagnosed with liver cirrhosis, which she was previously unaware of. She was also found to be leukopenic and thrombocytopenic. She was started on prednisone taper starting with 40 mg for 10 then slow taper. She was also evaluated by rheumatology and serology was concerning for SLE and she was started on plaquenil 200 BID. Due to significant dryness symptoms, she was also started on pilocarpine. She was discharged and instructed to follow up with cardiology, pulmonology, GI, rheumatology and hematology. 

The patient has a history of lupus dating back to the 1980s and was followed by a rheumatologist in Jersey City who is now retired. Her initial presentation included joint pain, primarily in the fingers with swelling. She was initially diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis and treated with gold shots and leflunomide. She was offered Plaquenil but declined due to concerns about side effects. She was also offered Rinvoq but did not try it. She has never been on biologics and was primarily managed with prednisone courses. No history of interna organ involvement before recent hospitalization. She had bilateral knee replacement for degenerative changes.  She also reports significant sicca symptoms for long time and previous diagnosis of sjogren syndrome. 

Prior to her recent hospitalization, she had a skin biopsy of her rash which confirmed discoid lupus or subcutaneous lupus which responded to topical steroid 

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (diagnosed 1980s)
2. Rheumatoid Arthritis
3. Sjogren's Syndrome
4. Graves' Disease
5. Severe Pulmonary Hypertension (diagnosed May 2025)
6. Liver Cirrhosis (diagnosed May 2025)
7. Leukopenia
8. Thrombocytopenia

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:
None documented

MEDICATIONS:
1. Prednisone (taper)
2. Hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil)
3. Pilocarpine

ALLERGIES:
None documented

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Not documented

FAMILY HISTORY:
Not documented

OCCUPATION:
Not documented

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
Constitutional: No fever, chills, or weight loss
HEENT: Dry eyes, dry mouth
Cardiovascular: No chest pain, palpitations
Respiratory: Shortness of breath
Gastrointestinal: No nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea
Genitourinary: No dysuria or hematuria

Skin: Rash on upper chest and back
Neurological: No headaches, seizures, or focal deficits
Psychiatric: No depression or anxiety
Endocrine: History of Graves' disease
Hematologic: Easy bruising, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
General: Well-appearing female in no acute distress
Vital Signs: Within normal limits
HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic
Neck: Supple, no lymphadenopathy
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended
Musculoskeletal: No signs of synovitis on exam
Skin: Bruising on upper extremities, periungual erythema in lower extremities, netlike livedo reticularis-type skin rashes over upper chest and upper back
Neurological: Alert and oriented, no focal deficits

LABORATORY FINDINGS:
- Positive ANA
- Low complements
- Slightly elevated SSA antibodies
- Leukopenia
- Thrombocytopenia
- Slightly elevated liver enzymes

ASSESSMENT:
1. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)  
-Patient fulfills criteria for lupus with positive ANA, low complements, slightly elevated SSA antibodies, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and skin rash confirmed as cutaneous lupus by biopsy. 
-Currently managed with prednisone and Plaquenil. 
-No evidence of CNS, nephrology involvement. No evidence of ILD. No signs of joint involvement. 
-Will monitor response to current therapy and consider additional immunosuppression if other organ involvement is identified.
-Should continue with plaquenil 200 mg BID
-For lupus related leukopenia, patient was treated with neupogen 
-For lupus related thrombocytopenia, patient was treated with steroids. Other options if no response include IVIG or RTX 
-For liver cirrhosis, will need to evaluate for lupus related hepatitis and autoimmune hepatitis. Patient is being evaluated by GI. Options will include Azathioprine.  

2. Severe Pulmonary Hypertension - Recently diagnosed by right cardiac catheterization. Patient is following with pulmonology for management. CT scan of chest does not show signs of interstitial lung disease.

3. Liver Cirrhosis - Recently diagnosed, currently being evaluated by gastroenterology for possible autoimmune liver disease. Liver enzymes are slightly elevated.

4. Sjogren's Syndrome - Significant dryness symptoms, currently managed with pilocarpine.

5. History of Rheumatoid Arthritis - Previously treated with gold shots and leflunomide. No current synovitis on examination.

6. Graves' Disease - No acute issues noted.

PLAN:
1. Continue prednisone taper as prescribed.
2. Continue Plaquenil two pills daily.
3. Continue pilocarpine for Sjogren's symptoms.
4. Obtain laboratory studies today to assess disease activity and medication response.
5. Await final liver evaluation from gastroenterology.
6. Assess for kidney involvement with urinalysis and renal function tests.
7. Follow up in one week to review laboratory results and adjust treatment plan as needed.
8. Consider additional immunosuppressive therapy if evidence of progressive organ involvement is found.
9. Continue coordination of care with pulmonology for management of pulmonary hypertension.
10. Continue to monitor blood cell count and follow up with hematology.

[REFERENCE NOTE3 START] 

 CHIEF COMPLAINT: Evaluation and management of joint pain

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
Ms. Hierro is a 49-year-old female who presents to the clinic for evaluation of joint pain. She reports experiencing pain throughout her entire body, particularly in large joints including the neck, shoulders, back, and knees. She also complains of finger swelling stating, "I cannot close them or open fast. I have to do some exercises so that they loose again." The swelling comes and goes. She notes that her joint pain worsens with changes in temperature, particularly when it rains. She experiences morning stiffness. The patient reports these symptoms have been ongoing for years.The patient also reports poor sleep, sleeping only about 4 hours per night with frequent interruptions. She works 10 hours per day. She has tried natural sleep aids prescribed by previous doctors without relief. She denies being evaluated by a sleep specialist.Additionally, she reports color changes in her hands, stating they turn "a really strong violet color" and that she has been losing sensitivity in her fingers with weather changes. She describes the color change starting with a yellowish-white color that then changes rapidly, but states that this happen with hot or cold weather. She experiences numbness in all ten fingers that occurs suddenly without apparent reason.The patient reports she was diagnosed with arthritis in Puerto Rico approximately 9-10 years ago. She has been prescribed prednisone, meloxicam, and Celebrex in the past. She states she has been on prednisone intermittently for about 9-10 years, with her last dose taken 5-6 months ago. She reports, "they've been changing also my medicines along the years, but I always go back to that medicine because it seems that my body is used to it."She reports a previous diagnosis of lupus but is not currently on any treatment for it. She has recently experienced irregular menstruation. Patient states that when she was young she was very flexible.  She was able to touch her thumb to the back of her forearms bilaterally she was able to touch the floor flat with her hands.  She was able to do splits easily.  Denied any shoulder dislocation.  She states she was able to move her knee particularly her left one out of place. Laboratory studies from June 2023 showed: WBC 5.1, hemoglobin 11.1, hematocrit 33.5, platelet count 216, glucose 84, BUN 13, creatinine 0.73, sodium 139, potassium 4.8, chloride 103, carbon dioxide 22, calcium 9.1, alkaline phosphatase 34, AST 37, ALT 22. Urinalysis did not show any RBCs or protein. Thyroid panel showed TSH 1.520, free T4 2.3 (within normal limits). Rheumatoid factor was less than 10. Vitamin D was 34.2. ESR was 26. ANA screen was positive.

INTERVAL HISTORY:
5/2/25: Patient returns for follow-up with recent laboratory and imaging results. Recent autoimmune panel shows negative anti-SCL 70 antibody, beta-2 glycoprotein IgA of 50, beta-2 glycoprotein IgG and IgM less than 9, albumin creatinine ratio of 8 (WNL), smooth muscle antibody of 6 (WNL), mitochondrial antibody less than 20, positive Sjogren SSA antibody (>8), negative SSB antibody, positive Smith antibody (>8), dsDNA of 2 (WNL), CCP antibody of 10, positive ANA at 1:1280 with speckled pattern, positive RNP antibody (>8), SCL70 less than 0.2, positive antichromatin antibody (>8), antiribosomal P antibody of 0.2, negative JO-1, negative anticentromere antibody, negative cold agglutinins, + thyroglobulin antibody of 2.1, and antithyroperoxidase antibody of 114. Urinalysis showed specific gravity of 1.025, 1+ protein, negative WBCs and RBCs.

MEDICATIONS:
Inside         Drug         Script Date         Qty         Rfls         Instructions                               celecoxib 200 mg capsule         4/18/2025                   0                                         clindamycin HCl 300 mg capsule         4/18/2025                   0                                         meloxicam 15 mg tablet         4/18/2025                   0                                         methylprednisolone 4 mg tablet         4/18/2025                   0                                         prednisone 5 mg tablet         4/18/2025                   0

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. 
HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic, extraocular movements intact, no oral ulcers noted. 
Chest: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. 
Heart: Normal S1, S2, regular rate and rhythm. 
Extremities: No pitting edema noted in upper or lower extremities. 
Skin: No skin rash noted. 
Musculoskeletal: No swelling noted in MCP, PIP, or DIP joints in left hand. Right hand fifth PIP joint is slightly tender and subjectively appears somewhat swollen. Tenderness noted throughout whole body with 16 out of 18 fibromyalgia trigger points positive.

ASSESSMENT:
1. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (+ ANA, +RNP, +Smith, +SSA) - Patient has positive ANA (1:1280 with speckled pattern), positive RNP antibody, positive Smith antibody (highly specific for lupus), positive antichromatin antibody, and positive SSA antibody. These findings strongly suggest an underlying inflammatory autoimmune connective tissue disease. Physical examination reveals slight soft tissue swelling in right fifth PIP joint. Will initiate hydroxychloroquine 5 mg/kg. Will also prescribe prednisone 20 mg with taper as a bridge while hydroxychloroquine takes effect.

2. Fibromyalgia - Patient's chronic pain is most consistent with fibromyalgia likely related to hypermobility based on her history. Patient reports history of flexibility in youth, poor sleep, and diffuse pain. Physical exam reveals tenderness at 16 of 18 trigger points. Will first address underlying autoimmune condition with hydroxychloroquine and may consider aqua therapy in the future. Recommended patient discuss fibromyalgia symptoms with her new primary care physician.

3. Raynaud's phenomenon - Patient reports color changes in her hands and fingers with associated numbness. Currently stable. Recommended conservative management including wearing mittens instead of gloves, multiple loose layers of clothing, and being consciously aware of environment. May consider calcium channel blocker in the future if symptoms worsen.

4. Hypermobility - Patient demonstrates hyperextension of elbows and reports history of flexibility. This likely contributes to her chronic pain symptoms.

5. Possible osteoarthritis - Based on history of joint pain that worsens with weather changes and previous diagnosis in Puerto Rico. Imaging shows chronic deformity of fifth DIP and PIP joint in right hand with soft tissue prominence of distal fifth finger. C-spine x-ray shows loss and flattening of normal cervical lordotic curvature, indicating possible paraspinal muscle spasms or strain.

PLAN:
Will start hydroxychloroquine 5 mg/kg - patient to take 200 mg Monday through Saturday and 400 mg on Sunday.
Recommend taking hydroxychloroquine with food in the evening.
Will prescribe prednisone 20 mg with taper as a bridge with concomitant use of hydroxychloroquine.
Patient has appointment with primary care doctor to establish care.


Patient to return to clinic in 8 weeks.

coding_information:
VISIT TYPE: Outpatient
NEW OR FOLLOW-UP: Follow-up
Complexity:
DIAGNOSIS: Recurrent moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the perianal skin, left side
ONSET: Chronic
STATUS: Unstable
COMPLEXITY: HIGH COMPLEXITY
Data:
IDENTIFIED CATEGORY 1: TEST and DOCUMENTS
1. Prior external notes were reviewed.  
2. TEST: CT scan report was reviewed.
3. TEST: PET scan was reviewed.
4. TEST: CBC and other labs were ordered.

IDENTIFIED CATEGORY 2: INDEPENDENT INTERPRETATION OF TESTS
1. TEST: CT scan was personally reviewed and interpreted or discussed with an external physician.
2. TEST: PET scan was personally reviewed and interpreted or discussed with an external physician.

IDENTIFIED CATEGORY 3: DISCUSSION OF MANAGEMENT OR TEST INTERPRETATION
1. DISCUSSION: Discussion with external physicians and other qualified health care professionals, including infectious disease specialist Dr. Nahass and radiation oncology specialists.  

DATA REVIEWED AND/OR ANALYZED: HIGH

Risk:
HIGH RISK
1. DECISION: Coordinating chemoradiation treatment with radiation oncology and infectious disease.
REASON: Drug therapy / Elective Major Surgery
plan:
1. Coordinating chemoradiation treatment with radiation oncology and infectious disease.
2. Ordered IV chemotherapy to be administered once radiation start date is confirmed.
3. Patient to continue oral chemotherapy pills during radiation treatment.
4. Sent message to radiation oncologist to coordinate start date for comprehensive treatment.
5. Will monitor CBC and other labs every 1-2 weeks during treatment.
6. Monitor for treatment side effects including hand-foot syndrome, mucositis, and bleeding.
7. Continue infectious disease management with Dr. Nahass who has cleared patient for concurrent treatments.
8. Patient to have two more infusions with infectious disease (one this Friday and one on approximately 07/07/25).
9. Follow up in 2 weeks after treatment initiation.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.

reviewed_note:
CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and management of recurrent perianal squamous cell carcinoma

DISEASE HISTORY:
Patient is a 63 year old HIV + pt who has a complex history of perianal disease. 
2009: He had excision of anal warts (condyloma acuminatum), positive for HSV. 
2011:  He had biopsies of perianal lesions, negative for malignancy. 
2012: In March of 2012, he had wide excision of perianal lesion (9 cm) with gluteal flap, with plastic surgery for skin grafting. Pathology of the wide excision showed HPV infection (focal equivocal) but no documented cancer. 
2013: The patient subsequently received radiation therapy from March 10, 2013 to April 10, 2013, with 3,600 cGy delivered to the perineum and a nodule. He had multiple resections of perianal warts before and after 2015. He also has a history of surgery for squamous cell carcinoma of scrotum. 
2023: Patient underwent colonoscopy in 2023 by Dr. Scully which showed polyps and a wound near the left anus, but biopsies were negative for malignancy.
2025: A repeat colonoscopy by Dr. Scully revealed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma on the left perianal area. HSV and HPV testing were negative on current biopsy. CT scan performed on 4-7-2025 showed a 7mm right upper lobe lung nodule, unchanged, and minimal stranding/inflammation in the left perianal tissues with no other significant findings. Patient reports pain with sitting following recent biopsy and occasional bleeding with wiping. Patient also reports intermittent pain in back, legs, and chest since the biopsy procedure.

INTERVAL HISTORY:
06/18/25: Patient presents for follow-up of recurrent perianal squamous cell carcinoma. Reports continued pain in the perianal area with drainage and odor. Patient has completed 2 infusions with infectious disease specialist Dr. Nahass for HSV treatment, with 2 additional infusions planned for Friday and approximately 7/7/25. Dr. Nahass has cleared patient to coordinate cancer treatment with chemoradiation. Patient received 5 days of antibiotics from Dr. Saeed for inflammation in left buttock area and was told the area looks better and he can start radiation. Patient has upcoming radiation oncology appointment on Friday. Reports pain in groin area when walking. Also reports nighttime cough which may be related to asthma.

ALLERGIES:
No known allergies
No known drug allergies

MEDICATIONS:
Continued medications: Dovato 50 mg-300 mg tablet, rosuvastatin 10 mg tablet.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. HEENT:PERRLA,EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear. Nodes: No peripheral adenopathy. Chest: Clear bilaterally. Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat. Abd: Soft, +BS, non tender and non distended, no masses, no organomegaly. Ext: No edema. Skin: Perianal area shows approximately 2x2 cm open wound with drainage. Area appears smaller than on previous examination. Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact. Musculoskeletal: Normal gait.

IMPRESSION:
Recurrent moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the perianal skin, left side (assuming had prior). Patient has complex history of perianal disease with prior wide excision in 2012 and radiation therapy from 3-12-2013 to 4-10-2013. Current biopsy confirms moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, now HSV and HPV negative. CT scan from 4-7-2025 shows minimal inflammatory changes in the left perianal region without evidence of metastatic disease. PET scan has identified lymph node involvement in the groin area. Currently has a 2cm open wound at the biopsy site, approximately 4-5cm from the anal opening with surrounding induration, appears smaller than previously noted. Treatment options are complex given prior radiation to the area. Standard treatment would include chemoradiation such as the Nigro protocol, but this may not be possible due to prior radiation exposure. He saw Dr. Saeed who is hopeful he could receive CRT given he did not receive full dose RT prior. He is due to see Rad onc shortly. Patient cleared by infectious disease specialist Dr. Nahass to proceed with concurrent chemoradiation therapy. Will coordinate with radiation oncology to review prior radiation records (from Dr. Gopal Desai in 2013), including radiation fields and total dose delivered (reported as 3,600 cGy to the primary area). Treatment plan will include oral chemotherapy during radiation treatments with IV chemotherapy on day 1 of week 1 and potentially day 1 of week 5 if blood counts remain adequate. Radiation fields will include coverage of identified groin lymph node. Awaiting radiation oncology to determine start date for coordinated treatment approach. Patient has received education regarding potential side effects. Plastic surgery evaluation may be needed to assess wound healing potential. Blood counts remain adequate for treatment initiation. 
History of recurrent condyloma acuminatum (anal warts) with multiple prior excisions. Complex history of recurrent perianal disease dating back to 2009. Initial diagnosis of condyloma acuminatum positive for HSV in 2009. Multiple subsequent excisions between 2009-2015 for recurrent disease. Patient reports prior treatment with topical cream with temporary improvement. Patient currently receiving targeted antiviral therapy with Dr. Nahass with 2 infusions completed and 2 additional sessions planned. Dr. Nahass reports improvement in inflammatory changes in left buttock area following antibiotic treatment. Concurrent HSV treatment being coordinated with cancer therapy as patient has dual pathology contributing to perianal disease process.
HIV positive, currently undetectable on medication. Currently maintained on Dovato with undetectable viral load. Followed regularly by infectious disease specialist Dr. Nahass every 3 months. Will coordinate cancer treatment plan with Dr. Nahass to ensure comprehensive care.
History of squamous cell carcinoma of scrotum, status post excision.
7mm right upper lobe lung nodule, unchanged from prior imaging. Stability suggests benign etiology. Will continue surveillance as part of routine cancer follow-up.
Lymphadenopathy in groin area noted on PET scan, likely related to primary perianal malignancy. Patient reports pain in groin area with walking. Radiation field will include this area.

PLAN:
Coordinating chemoradiation treatment with radiation oncology and infectious disease.
Ordered IV chemotherapy to be administered once radiation start date is confirmed.
Patient to continue oral chemotherapy pills during radiation treatment.
Sent message to radiation oncologist to coordinate start date for comprehensive treatment.
Will monitor CBC and other labs every 1-2 weeks during treatment.
Monitor for treatment side effects including hand-foot syndrome, mucositis, and bleeding.
Continue infectious disease management with Dr. Nahass who has cleared patient for concurrent treatments.
Patient to have two more infusions with infectious disease (one this Friday and one on approximately 07/07/25).
Follow up in 2 weeks after treatment initiation.

Patient has given prior verbal consent to have the conversation recorded and summarized by the Knowtex software.

You need to capture all medical information relevant to an oncologist. 
Write the note in formal language like an oncologist would, using medical terminology and being objective.

I am going to give you a conversation to summarize into a note.

If there are new diagnoses, add them to this section in the same formatting as the other diagnoses

If there are any direct dictations in the transcript, insert the dictated sentences verbatim into the pertinent sections.

Use the provided starting note and fill out the rest of it.
Only output the generated note and nothing else.

There are also some reference notes from the same doctor; you may reference their style, language, and formatting.

Message(id='msg_01XBpokTS3oybJZfSwUZcsXt', content=[TextBlock(citations=None, text='CHIEF COMPLAINT:
Evaluation and management of recurrent perianal squamous cell carcinoma

DISEASE HISTORY:
Patient is a 63 year old HIV + pt who has a complex history of perianal disease. 2009: He had excision of anal warts (condyloma acuminatum), positive for HSV. 2011:  He had biopsies of perianal lesions, negative for malignancy. 2012: In March of 2012, he had wide excision of perianal lesion (9 cm) with gluteal flap, with plastic surgery for skin grafting. Pathology of the wide excision showed HPV infection (focal equivocal) but no documented cancer. 2013: The patient subsequently received radiation therapy from March 10, 2013 to April 10, 2013, with 3,600 cGy delivered to the perineum and a nodule. He had multiple resections of perianal warts before and after 2015. He also has a history of surgery for squamous cell carcinoma of scrotum. 2023: Patient underwent colonoscopy in 2023 by Dr. Scully which showed polyps and a wound near the left anus, but biopsies were negative for malignancy. 2025: A repeat colonoscopy by Dr. Scully revealed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma on the left perianal area. HSV and HPV testing were negative on current biopsy. CT scan performed on 4-7-2025 showed a 7mm right upper lobe lung nodule, unchanged, and minimal stranding/inflammation in the left perianal tissues with no other significant findings. Patient reports pain with sitting following recent biopsy and occasional bleeding with wiping. Patient also reports intermittent pain in back, legs, and chest since the biopsy procedure.

INTERVAL HISTORY:
06/18/25: Patient presents for follow-up of recurrent perianal squamous cell carcinoma. Reports continued pain in the perianal area with drainage and odor. Has been seen by Dr. Nahas who prescribed a 5-day course of antibiotics for inflammation. Patient reports the area is still painful but Dr. Saeed noted it "looks better" and cleared patient to start radiation therapy. Patient has upcoming radiation oncology appointment on Friday. Reports pain in groin area when walking. Also reports nighttime cough which may be related to asthma.

ALLERGIES:
No known allergies
No known drug allergies

MEDICATIONS:
Continued medications: Dovato 50 mg-300 mg tablet, rosuvastatin 10 mg tablet.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
The ROS is negative in 12 point detail except for the pertinent positives and negatives listed in HPI and below

OBJECTIVE:
Physical Examination:
Gen: Well developed well nourished. HEENT:PERRLA,EOMI, sclera anicteric, oropharynx clear. Nodes: No peripheral adenopathy. Chest: Clear bilaterally. Heart: S1 S2 no murmurs, regular heartbeat. Abd: Soft, +BS, non tender and non distended, no masses, no organomegaly. Ext: No edema. Skin: Perianal area shows approximately 2x2 cm open wound with drainage. Area appears smaller than on previous examination. Neuro: motor and sensory grossly intact. Musculoskeletal: Normal gait.

IMPRESSION:
1. Recurrent moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the perianal skin, left side (assuming had prior). Patient has complex history of perianal disease with prior wide excision in 2012 and radiation therapy from 3-12-2013 to 4-10-2013. Current biopsy confirms moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, now HSV and HPV negative. CT scan from 4-7-2025 shows minimal inflammatory changes in the left perianal region without evidence of metastatic disease. Currently has a 2cm open wound at the biopsy site, approximately 4-5cm from the anal opening with surrounding induration. Treatment options are complex given prior radiation to the area. Standard treatment would include chemoradiation such as the Nigro protocol, but this may not be possible due to prior radiation exposure. He saw Dr. Saeed who is hopeful he could receive CRT given he did not receive full dose RT prior. He is due to see Rad onc shortly. Will coordinate with radiation oncology to review prior radiation records (from Dr. Gopal Desai in 2013), including radiation fields and total dose delivered (reported as 3,600 cGy to the primary area). PET scan scheduled for 05/15/25 to evaluate for metastatic disease. Radiation oncology consultation ordered. Treatment plan will include oral chemotherapy during radiation treatments with IV chemotherapy on day 1 of week 1 and potentially day 1 of week 5 if blood counts remain adequate. Discussed potential side effects including risk of wound complications given patient's history of requiring skin grafting after previous radiation. Plastic surgery evaluation may be needed to assess wound healing potential. Patient expresses understanding of treatment plan and anxiety about potential disease spread.
2. History of recurrent condyloma acuminatum (anal warts) with multiple prior excisions. Complex history of recurrent perianal disease dating back to 2009. Initial diagnosis of condyloma acuminatum positive for HSV in 2009. Multiple subsequent excisions between 2009-2015 for recurrent disease. Patient reports prior treatment with topical cream with temporary improvement. Will ensure coordination with infectious disease regarding ongoing management.
3. HIV positive, currently undetectable on medication. Currently maintained on Dovato with undetectable viral load. Followed regularly by infectious disease specialist Dr. Nahass every 3 months. Will coordinate cancer treatment plan with Dr. Nahass to ensure comprehensive care.
4. History of squamous cell carcinoma of scrotum, status post excision.
5. 7mm right upper lobe lung nodule, unchanged from prior imaging. Stability suggests benign etiology. Will continue surveillance as part of routine cancer follow-up.
6. Lymphadenopathy in groin area noted on PET scan, likely related to primary perianal malignancy. Patient reports pain in groin area with walking. Radiation field will include this area.

PLAN:
1. Coordinating chemoradiation treatment with radiation oncology and infectious disease.
2. Ordered IV chemotherapy to be administered once radiation start date is confirmed.
3. Patient to continue oral chemotherapy pills during radiation treatment.
4. Sent message to radiation oncologist to coordinate start date for comprehensive treatment.
5. Will monitor CBC and other labs every 1-2 weeks during treatment.
6. Monitor for treatment side effects including hand-foot syndrome, mucositis, and bleeding.
7. Continue infectious disease management with Dr. Nahass who has cleared patient for concurrent treatments.
8. Patient to have two more infusions with infectious disease (one this Friday and one on approximately 07/07/25).
9. Follow up in 2 weeks after treatment initiation.

icd10_codes.icd10_res:
Primary
1. C44.520 - Squamous cell carcinoma of anal skin

Secondary
1. Z85.048 - Personal history of other malignant neoplasm of rectum, rectosigmoid junction, and anus
2. Z86.008 - Personal history of in-situ neoplasm of other site (History of squamous cell carcinoma in situ)
3. A60.1 - Herpesviral infection of perianal skin and rectum (history of recurrent condyloma acuminatum or anal warts)
4. R85.610 - Atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance on cytologic smear of anus (previous biopsies)
5. C44.500 - Unspecified malignant neoplasm of anal skin (squamous cell carcinoma of scrotum)
